Principles and Problems

  • Write a Principle
    • Kinematics
      • Translational
        • v(avg) = s/t  average speed
          • Translational Kinematics
            KT1A26197The SR-71 strategic reconnaissance aircraft, the Blackbird,
            set a world speed record by flying from London to Los
            Angeles (8,790 km) in 3 hr 47 min 36 s.

            Compute the average speed in meters per second (m/s).
            Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            KT1B17698.5The SR-71 strategic reconnaissance aircraft, the Blackbird,
            set a world speed record by flying from London to Los
            Angeles. It recaptured the 1000-km (1,000,000 m)
            closed-circuit-course record (previously held by the Russian
            MIG-25 Foxbat) at an average speed of 935 m/s.

            How long was the flight (in s)?
            Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            KT2A82975Suppose you fire a bullet (speed 1600 m/s) in a shooting
            gallery and hear the gong on the target ring 0.731 s later.

            Taking the speed of sound to be 330 m/s and assuming the
            bullet travels straight downrange at a constant speed, how
            far does the bullet travel before hitting the target?
            Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            KT2B10104Julie drives 100 mi to Grandmother's house. On the way to
            Grandmother's, Julie drives half the distance at 35 mi/hr and
            half the distance at 55 mi/hr. What is Julie's average speed
            on the way to Grandmother's house?
            Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]

            On her return trip, she drives half the time at 35 mi/hr and
            half the time at 55 mi/hr. What is Julie's average speed on
            the return trip?
            Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            KT3A114883A motorcyclist rides onto a road at 22.2 m/s at 1200 noon
            and maintains that speed for the rest of her journey. At 1300
            a car traveling at 27.8 m/s turns onto the road at the same
            point as did the motorcycle.

            How many seconds after the motorcycle started will it be
            passed by the car?
            Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            How far down the road does the car travel before this occurs?
            Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            KT3B753.585A Chevy is being driven down a long straight road at 42.0 mi/hr
            starting a 10:00 am. It maintains that speed for the rest of
            its journey. At 10:30 am, a BMW traveling at 80.0 mi/hr turns
            onto the road at the point where the Chevy started.
            How long has the Chevy been traveling when the BMW
            passes it?
            Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            How far down the road will the cars pass?
            Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            KT4A34893A bumblebee flew 43.0 m along a twisting path only to land on
            a flower 3.00 m due south of the point on its hive from which
            it started.

            If the entire journey took 10.0 s, what were the average speed
            and the magnitude of the average velocity of the bumblebee?
            Avg speed: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            Avg velocity: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            KT4B117166On a timed course a jogger runs 280 m in a direction
            45 degrees north of west, then 417 m toward the west and
            finallly 390 m in a direction 40 degrees south of east.
            If the course is completed in 180 s, find the average speed
            and the magnitude and direction of the average velocity
            of the jogger on the course.
            average speed: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            average velocity:
            magnitude [XXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            direction [XXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            KT4COn a timed course a jogger runs 417 m toward the west and
            then 390 m in a direction 40 degrees south of east.
            If the course is completed in 120 s, find the average speed
            and the magnitude and direction of the average velocity
            of the jogger on the course.
            average speed: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            average velocity:
            magnitude [XXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            direction [XXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            KT14A39679A runner running on a 400 m circular track is running in the
            direction shown in the figure below. If the runner starts from
            point 1 and reaches point 2 in 28.5 seconds, find the average
            speed and the average velocity of the runner during this time
            period.
            average speed: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            average velocity:
            x-component [XXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            y-component [XXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            KT14B119438A runner is running on a 400 m circular track at a constant
            speed of 7.8 m/s in the direction shown in the figure below.
            Find the values for the instantaneous acceleration at point 2
            and the average acceleration between points 1 and 2.
            Instantaneous acceleration at 2:
            x-component [XXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            y-component [XXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            Average acceleration between points 1 and 2:
            x-component [XXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            y-component [XXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
          • Waves
            WAVE4364.589A 0.5 kg rope is stretched between two supports
            that are 5.2 m apart. When one support is struck,
            a transverse wave travels down the length of the
            rope in 0.90 s. What is the tension in the rope?
            [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
          • Electromagnetic Waves
            WAVE1934974A laser pulse is bounced off of a reflector on the Moon and
            returns to the Earth's surface. If the distance from the
            surface of the Moon to the surface of the Earth during this
            time is 3.84e8 m, what time is required for the round trip?
            [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
        • v(avg)_x = d_x/t  average velocity
          • Vectors
            MOT4102792The figure below shows the motion diagram, made at two
            frames of film per second, of a ball rolling along a track.
            The track has a 0.45 m long sticky section between .40 m and
            0.85 m. Note: to solve this problem, you will need to draw
            axes and several vectors.

            Find the ball's average velocity before reaching the sticky
            section of the track (between times T0 and T1).
            Velocity (x component): [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            Find the ball's average velocity after leaving the sticky
            section of the track (between T2 and T3).
            Velocity (x component): [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            Determine the ball's average acceleration on the sticky
            section of the track (between T1 and T2).
            Acceleration (x component): [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]



          • Kinematics Graphs
            KGRAPH1026442The graph shown below describes the motion of an object
            that is moving along the x-axis.
            Find the x-component of the object's average velocity
            between 0 and 3 s.
            (To do this, you will need to draw the associated
            displacement and velocity vectors.)
            x-component of velocity: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]






            Next, find the x-component of the average velocity between
            3 and 6 seconds.
            x-component of velocity: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]

            KT4B117166On a timed course a jogger runs 280 m in a direction
            45 degrees north of west, then 417 m toward the west and
            finallly 390 m in a direction 40 degrees south of east.
            If the course is completed in 180 s, find the average speed
            and the magnitude and direction of the average velocity
            of the jogger on the course.

            average velocity:
            magnitude [XXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            direction [XXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            KT4COn a timed course a jogger runs 417 m toward the west and

            If the course is completed in 120 s, find the average speed

            KT7B6329A car is traveling at a constant velocity v0 when the driver
            notices a garbage can on the road in front of him. At that
            moment, the distance between the garbage can and the front
            of the car is d. After time T01 passes, the driver applies
            the brakes and slows down at a constant rate before coming
            to a halt just before the garbage can. Find the magnitude
            of the car's acceleration after the brakes are applied, in
            terms of v0, d, and t01.
            Acceleration: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            You will need to do the algebra by hand.
            KT12A64692A cannon is on the slope of a hill 100.0 m down the slope from
            a castle. The slope makes an angle of 13.0 deg with respect
            to the horizontal. If the cannon is pointed 40.0 deg above
            the horizontal and fires at the castle, what is the magnitude of
            the initial velocity if the cannonball is to hit the castle?

            Note: Assume the cannonball hits at the base of the castle wall.
            Ignore the effects if air resistance.
            Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            KT12B46439A cannon is on the slope of a hill 132.6 m down the slope from a
            castle. The slope makes an angle of 12.0 deg with respect to the
            horizontal. If the cannon is pointed 45.0 deg above the
            horizontal and hits the base of the castle wall, what will be the
            x and y components of the velocity of the cannonball as it hits
            the wall? HINT: Use a horizontal x axis.
            x-component: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            y-component: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            KT14A39679A runner running on a 400 m circular track is running in the
            direction shown in the figure below. If the runner starts from
            point 1 and reaches point 2 in 28.5 seconds, find the average
            speed and the average velocity of the runner during this time
            period.
            average speed: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            average velocity:
            x-component [XXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            y-component [XXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
          • Power
            POW5A1205.557What average power output from the car's engine is required for
            a 1200 kg car to climb a 2.00 km long 11.0 deg hill in 100 s?
            Assume the only retarding force is an air drag force with a
            magnitude of 700 N and that the speed of the car is constant.
            Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
        • v(avg)_y = d_y/t  average velocity
          • Translational Kinematics

            KT5A78180An observer on a golf course stands 60.0 m west of the
            tee as a player drives a ball down the fairway. The ball
            lands at a point due north of where it started.

            If the ball lands 2.00 s later, 156 m from the observer,
            what was its average velocity during its flight?
            Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]

            a castle. The slope makes an angle of 13.0 deg with respect
            to the horizontal. If the cannon is pointed 40.0 deg above

            Note: Assume the cannonball hits at the base of the castle wall.
            Ignore the effects if air resistance.

          • Power
            POW2A36884A coffee filter with a mass of 2.00 g falling at terminal velocity
            falls 1.00 m in 1.83 s. What is the net average power supplied
            to the coffee filter by all forces during this 1.83 s?
            Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            POW5A1205.557What average power output from the car's engine is required for
            a 1200 kg car to climb a 2.00 km long 11.0 deg hill in 100 s?
            Assume the only retarding force is an air drag force with a
            magnitude of 700 N and that the speed of the car is constant.
            Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
        • a(avg)_x = (vf_x - vi_x)/t 
          • Vectors
            VEC6A937.589At t = 0.00 s, a particle moving in the xy plane has a velocity
            of (3.00 i - 2.00 j) m/s at the origin. At t = 3.00 s, the particle's
            velocity is (9.00 i + 7.00 j) m/s.

            Find the average acceleration of the particle expressed in
            component form.
            Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX] i + [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX] j
            VEC6B39597At time t0, a particle moving in the xy plane has a velocity
            of (3.00 i + 4.00 j) m/s at the origin. At time t1 the particle's
            velocity is (- 1.00 i + 2.00 j) m/s. Its average acceleration
            over the time interval is (- 8.00 i - 4.00 j) m/s^2.

            Find the length of the time interval.
            Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            VEC6C44998At t = 0 s, a particle moving in the xy plane has a velocity
            of (4.00 i + 2.00 j) m/s at the origin. Its average acceleration
            over the next 3.00 s is (6.00 i + 7.00 j) m/s^2.

            Find the velocity of the particle at t=3.00 s expressed
            in component form.
            Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX] i + [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX] j
            VEC6D43998At t = 5.00 s, a particle moving in the xy plane has a velocity
            of (15.0 i + 18.0 j) m/s at the origin. Its average acceleration
            over the previous 5.00 s was (3.00 i + 2.00 j) m/s^2.

            Find the velocity of the particle at t = 0 s expressed in
            component form.
            Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX] i + [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX] j
            VEC8A51098An airplane is flying at 207 m/s in a direction of 57 deg with
            respect to the x-axis. The pilot receives instructions to change
            course. After a time interval of 145 s its velocity is 243 m/s
            in a direction of 324 deg with respect to the standard x-axis.
            Find the x and y components of the average acceleration during
            the change of course.
            x-component: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            y-component: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            VEC8B55298A runner is running laps at a velocity with constant magnitude
            of 3.30 m/s. As he rounds the curve his direction changes from
            137 deg to 243 deg with respect to the standard x-axis, within a
            period of 3.72 s. Find the x and y components of the average
            acceleration during this time interval.
            x component: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            y component: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            VEC8C37899A NASCAR racer is driving at a velocity with constant magnitude
            of 82.4 m/s. As he rounds the curve his direction changes from
            258 deg to 351 deg with respect to the standard x-axis, within a
            period of 7.23 s. Find the x and y components of the average
            acceleration during this time interval.
            x component: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            y component: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            MOT4102792The figure below shows the motion diagram, made at two
            frames of film per second, of a ball rolling along a track.
            The track has a 0.45 m long sticky section between .40 m and
            0.85 m. Note: to solve this problem, you will need to draw
            axes and several vectors.

            Find the ball's average velocity before reaching the sticky
            section of the track (between times T0 and T1).
            Velocity (x component): [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]

            section of the track (between T2 and T3).
            Velocity (x component): [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            Determine the ball's average acceleration on the sticky
            section of the track (between T1 and T2).
            Acceleration (x component): [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]



          • Kinematics Graphs
            KGRAPH1630335Below is a plot of velocity versus time for a particle that
            is travelling along the x-axis.
            Use the velocity plot to find the total distance travelled
            by the particle.
            Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            Find the average acceleration of the particle over
            the first 2.0 seconds. You will need to draw
            several vectors to answer this question.






            Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            Use the velocity graph to find the instantaneous
            acceleration of the particle at t=5 s. (You may answer this
            question without drawing any vectors.)
            Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
          • Translational Kinematics
            KT6A30795A motorcyclist races along a flat road with an initial velocity
            of 1.00 m/s. At the finish line, 62.0 s later, he reaches a
            velocity of 15.0 m/s.

            Find the magnitude of the average acceleration.
            Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            KT6B56593A finalist in the Soap Box Derby starts with a push down a
            long hill with a slope of 6.00 deg. The magnitude of its
            initial velocity is 1.00 m/s. At the bottom, 62.0 s later,
            its velocity reaches 15.0 m/s.

            Find the magnitude of its average acceleration.
            Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            KT7A132775A modern supertanker is gigantic: 1200 to 1300 ft long with
            a 200 ft beam. Fully loaded, it chugs along at about 16.0 knots
            (8.33 m/s). It can take 1200 s to bring it to a full stop.

            Calculate the magnitude of the corresponding acceleration
            in m/s and determine the magnitude of the displacement
            of the tanker as it slows to a stop.
            Acceleration: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            Displacement: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            KT7B6329A car is traveling at a constant velocity v0 when the driver
            notices a garbage can on the road in front of him. At that
            moment, the distance between the garbage can and the front
            of the car is d. After time T01 passes, the driver applies
            the brakes and slows down at a constant rate before coming
            to a halt just before the garbage can. Find the magnitude
            of the car's acceleration after the brakes are applied, in
            terms of v0, d, and t01.
            Acceleration: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            You will need to do the algebra by hand.
            KT8A98168A motorboat starting from a dead stop accelerates to the right
            at a constant 2.00 m/s^2 for 3.00 s, then very rapidly roars up
            to 4.00 m/s^2 and holds the acceleration constant.
            What is its approximate average acceleration over the
            first 5.00 s of its motion?
            Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            KT8B74267A car can go from rest to a velocity of 22.4 m/s in 8.20 seconds.
            Assuming its acceleration is constant in the x-direction, how
            long will it take for the velocity to change from 13.4 m/s to
            17.9 m/s?
            Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            KT14B119438A runner is running on a 400 m circular track at a constant
            speed of 7.8 m/s in the direction shown in the figure below.
            Find the values for the instantaneous acceleration at point 2
            and the average acceleration between points 1 and 2.
            Instantaneous acceleration at 2:
            x-component [XXXXXXXXXXXXXX]

            Average acceleration between points 1 and 2:
            x-component [XXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            y-component [XXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
          • Translational Dynamics
            DT1A57272Suppose a car stopped on the road is hit from behind
            by a bus so that it accelerates up to 4.47 m/s (10.0 mph)
            in 0.100 s.

            If the driver of the car has a mass of 50.0 kg, what average
            net force is exerted on her during the crash?
            Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            DT1B37276An F-14A jet with a mass of 32,000 kg has a typical lift-off
            distance of 900 m and a corresponding liftoff speed of
            70.0 m/s.

            Assuming its acceleration is constant, calculate the average
            net force on the jet in newtons. Ignore the effect of friction
            and air drag.
            Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            DT3A41888Suppose a 0.006 kg bullet traveling at 100.0 m/s strikes
            a bulletproof vest and comes to a rest in about 0.005 s.

            What average force does the bullet exert on the vest?
            Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            DT3B428.554A modern nuclear aircraft carrier has a mass of around
            9.0e7 kg and is capable of traveling in excess of 30.0 knots
            (15.4 m/s).

            Suppose one of these giants plowed into a pier at 30.0 knots,
            coming to rest in 30.0 seconds, what average force would the
            carrier exert on the pier?
            Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            DT3CA car travelling at 10.0 m/s is involved in a head-on crash. The driver,
            whose mass is 60.0 kg, is to be brought to rest within the
            passenger compartment by uniformly compressing an
            inflated air bag through a distance of 0.30 m.

            Find the average force exerted on the air bag by the driver
            during the collision.
            Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            DT5A46682A 2000-kg car in neutral at the top of a 20.0 deg inclined
            driveway 20.0 m long slips its parking brake and rolls down.

            If we ignore friction and drag, what is the magnitude
            of the car's velocity when it hits the garage door?

            Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            DT9BA box slides a distance of 3.48 m down a plane which makes
            a 30.0 deg angle with the horizontal. The mass of the box is
            6.21 kg. The frictional force on the box is 13.1 N. What is
            the magnitude of the box's velocity when it reaches the
            bottom of the plane if it started from rest?

            Use Newton's laws to solve this problem.
            Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
          • Work and Energy
            WE6779.589.5A 58 kg box slides on a horizontal surface as shown below.
            When the box reaches p1, it is sliding at a speed of 3.7 m/s.
            At p1 the box slides onto a region that has friction and
            it slows to a stop in 5.2 m. Assuming the coefficient of
            kinetic friction between the box and the surface is constant,
            find the value of the coefficient.
            [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
          • Power
            POW6A103263A physics student decides to measure the power required for
            his 1900 kg car to maintain a constant speed of 24.6 m/s
            (55 mph) on level ground. To get the necessary data, he
            puts the car into neutral (coasting) and finds that during
            a period of 7.5 s, the speed drops from 25.7 m/s (57.5 mph)
            to 23.5 m/s (52.5 mph). Use these data to calculate
            the drag force acting on the car under while slowing down
            on level ground.
            [XXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            Now, use this result to find the power required from
            the car's engine to maintain the car at a constant speed
            of 24.6 m/s (55 mph).
            [XXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            Assume the car is moving to the right.
          • Linear Momentum
            IMP157877A 0.145 kg baseball pitched at 40 m/s is hit on
            a horizontal line back to the pitcher at 52 m/s.
            If the contact time of the ball with the bat is
            4.7e-3 s, calculate the magnitude of the average
            force acting on the ball due the bat.
            [XXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            Assume the batter is to the right of the pitcher.
          • Electric Field
            FOR11B85358A electron with a charge of -1.6e-19 C and a mass of
            9.11e-31 kg starts at rest in a region with a uniform
            electric field of 1500 N/C in the positive x direction.
            What will be the kinetic energy of the electron after it
            has been accelerated through a distance of 2.5 cm?
            Energy: [XXXXXXXXXXXX]
            In this problem, gravity can be ignored.
            FOR11C66969A electron with a charge of -1.6e-19 C and a mass of
            9.11e-31 kg starts at rest in a region with a uniform
            electric field of 1500 N/C in the positive x direction.
            What will be the kinetic energy of the electron after it
            has been accelerated for 15 ns?
            Energy: [XXXXXXXXXXXX]
            In this problem, gravity can be ignored.
            ELEC4B485.589A proton (qp = 1.60e-19 C; mp = 1.67e-27 kg) is in a region where
            there is a uniform electric field E of magnitude 320 N/C, directed
            along the positive x-axis. The proton accelerates from rest and
            reaches a speed of 1.20e+5 m/s. How long does it take the proton to
            reach this speed?
            Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXX]
            In this problem, gravity can be ignored.
            ELEC5B43988A proton (qp = 1.60e-19 C; mp = 1.67e-27 kg) is in a region where
            there is a uniform electric field E of magnitude 920 N/C, directed
            along the negative x-axis. The proton accelerates from rest and
            reaches a speed of 7.2e+3 m/s. How far does the proton travel
            during this duration?
            Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXX]
            In this problem, gravity can be ignored.
        • a(avg)_y = (vf_y - vi_y)/t 
          • Vectors
            VEC6A937.589At t = 0.00 s, a particle moving in the xy plane has a velocity
            of (3.00 i - 2.00 j) m/s at the origin. At t = 3.00 s, the particle's
            velocity is (9.00 i + 7.00 j) m/s.

            Find the average acceleration of the particle expressed in
            component form.
            Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX] i + [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX] j
            VEC6B39597At time t0, a particle moving in the xy plane has a velocity
            of (3.00 i + 4.00 j) m/s at the origin. At time t1 the particle's
            velocity is (- 1.00 i + 2.00 j) m/s. Its average acceleration
            over the time interval is (- 8.00 i - 4.00 j) m/s^2.

            Find the length of the time interval.
            Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            VEC6C44998At t = 0 s, a particle moving in the xy plane has a velocity

            over the next 3.00 s is (6.00 i + 7.00 j) m/s^2.

            Find the velocity of the particle at t=3.00 s expressed
            in component form.

            Find the velocity of the particle at t = 0 s expressed in
            component form.

            VEC8C37899A NASCAR racer is driving at a velocity with constant magnitude
            of 82.4 m/s. As he rounds the curve his direction changes from
            258 deg to 351 deg with respect to the standard x-axis, within a
            period of 7.23 s. Find the x and y components of the average
            acceleration during this time interval.

            y component: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]

            of the bullet.

            KT12A64692A cannon is on the slope of a hill 100.0 m down the slope from
            a castle. The slope makes an angle of 13.0 deg with respect
            to the horizontal. If the cannon is pointed 40.0 deg above
            the horizontal and fires at the castle, what is the magnitude of
            the initial velocity if the cannonball is to hit the castle?

            Note: Assume the cannonball hits at the base of the castle wall.
            Ignore the effects if air resistance.

            KT12B46439A cannon is on the slope of a hill 132.6 m down the slope from a
            castle. The slope makes an angle of 12.0 deg with respect to the
            horizontal. If the cannon is pointed 45.0 deg above the
            horizontal and hits the base of the castle wall, what will be the
            x and y components of the velocity of the cannonball as it hits
            the wall? HINT: Use a horizontal x axis.
            x-component: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            y-component: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            KT12C100059A cannon is on the slope of a hill 132.6 m down the slope from
            a castle. The slope makes an angle of 12.0 deg with respect
            to the horizontal. If the cannon is pointed 45.0 deg above
            the horizontal and has a muzzle velcity of 40.2 m/s, what will
            be the x and y components of the velocity of the cannonball as
            it hits the wall.
            x-component: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            y-component: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            Note that the x-component of the displacement of the cannonball
            during T0 to T1 is equal to the x-component of the relative
            position of the castle with respect to the cannon.
            KT13A469.550.5A boy is playing catch with himself by throwing a ball
            straight up. How fast does he throw the ball if it comes back
            to his hands a second later?

            At low speeds air friction is negligible.

            DT1C53478During a parachute jump over Alaska in 1955, a United
            States trooper jumped from a C-119 at 400 m, but his
            chute failed to open. He was found alive at the bottom
            of a 1.00 m crater in the snow.

            Compute the average net force that acted on him as he
            plowed into the snow.
            Assume the deceleration was constant. The mass of the
            trooper was 90.0 kg and his speed when he hit the snow
            was 20.0 m/s.
            Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]

            FOR11A1063.548.5A fully ionized alpha particle with a charge of 3.20e-19 C
            and a mass of 6.64e-27 kg is initially moving in
            the x direction with a velocity of 1.50e+3 m/s. The particle
            enters a region where there is a uniform electric field in
            the positive y direction with a magnitude of 2.50e+2 N/C.
            What will be the velocity of the particle after it has
            moved 0.500 m in the x direction?
            x-component: [XXXXXXXXXXXX]
            y-component: [XXXXXXXXXXXX]
            In this problem, gravity can be ignored.
            ELEC3B90159An electron (qe = -1.60e-19 C; me = 9.11e-31 kg) is in a region,
            between two parallel charged plates, that produce a uniform electric
            field E of magnitude 2.0e+4 N/C. The separation between the plates
            is 1.5 cm. The electron undergoes a constant acceleration from rest
            near the negative plate and passes through a tiny hole in the positive
            plate (see Figure below). Find the velocity of the electron as it leaves
            the hole.
            Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXX]
            In this problem, gravity can be ignored.
            ELEC6B1086.539An electron (qe = -1.60e-19 C; me = 9.11e-31 kg) is in a region near
            the surface of the earth where there is a uniform electric field E
            of magnitude 4.0e-12 N/C, directed along the negative y-axis.
            The electron is moving in the positive y-direction at an initial
            velocity of 4.3 m/s. How far will the electron travel before it
            momentarily comes to rest?
            Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXX]
            In this problem, please include gravity.
        • d_x = v0_x*t + 0.5*a_x*t^2  [a_x is constant]
          • Translational Kinematics
            KT7A132775A modern supertanker is gigantic: 1200 to 1300 ft long with
            a 200 ft beam. Fully loaded, it chugs along at about 16.0 knots
            (8.33 m/s). It can take 1200 s to bring it to a full stop.

            Calculate the magnitude of the corresponding acceleration
            in m/s and determine the magnitude of the displacement
            of the tanker as it slows to a stop.
            Acceleration: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            Displacement: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]

            notices a garbage can on the road in front of him. At that
            moment, the distance between the garbage can and the front
            of the car is d. After time T01 passes, the driver applies
            the brakes and slows down at a constant rate before coming
            to a halt just before the garbage can. Find the magnitude
            of the car's acceleration after the brakes are applied, in
            terms of v0, d, and t01.
            Acceleration: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            You will need to do the algebra by hand.

            at a constant 2.00 m/s^2 for 3.00 s, then very rapidly roars up

            What is its approximate average acceleration over the
            first 5.00 s of its motion?

            VEC6A937.589At t = 0.00 s, a particle moving in the xy plane has a velocity
            of (3.00 i - 2.00 j) m/s at the origin. At t = 3.00 s, the particle's
            velocity is (9.00 i + 7.00 j) m/s.

            Find the average acceleration of the particle expressed in
            component form.
            Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX] i + [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX] j

            of (3.00 i + 4.00 j) m/s at the origin. At time t1 the particle's
            velocity is (- 1.00 i + 2.00 j) m/s. Its average acceleration
            over the time interval is (- 8.00 i - 4.00 j) m/s^2.

            Find the length of the time interval.
            Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            VEC6C44998At t = 0 s, a particle moving in the xy plane has a velocity
            of (4.00 i + 2.00 j) m/s at the origin. Its average acceleration
            over the next 3.00 s is (6.00 i + 7.00 j) m/s^2.

            Find the velocity of the particle at t=3.00 s expressed
            in component form.
            Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX] i + [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX] j

            Find the velocity of the particle at t = 0 s expressed in
            component form.

            KT7B6329A car is traveling at a constant velocity v0 when the driver
            notices a garbage can on the road in front of him. At that
            moment, the distance between the garbage can and the front
            of the car is d. After time T01 passes, the driver applies
            the brakes and slows down at a constant rate before coming
            to a halt just before the garbage can. Find the magnitude
            of the car's acceleration after the brakes are applied, in
            terms of v0, d, and t01.
            Acceleration: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            You will need to do the algebra by hand.
            KT8A98168A motorboat starting from a dead stop accelerates to the right
            at a constant 2.00 m/s^2 for 3.00 s, then very rapidly roars up
            to 4.00 m/s^2 and holds the acceleration constant.
            What is its approximate average acceleration over the
            first 5.00 s of its motion?
            Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            KT8B74267A car can go from rest to a velocity of 22.4 m/s in 8.20 seconds.
            Assuming its acceleration is constant in the x-direction, how
            long will it take for the velocity to change from 13.4 m/s to
            17.9 m/s?
            Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            KT14B119438A runner is running on a 400 m circular track at a constant
            speed of 7.8 m/s in the direction shown in the figure below.
            Find the values for the instantaneous acceleration at point 2
            and the average acceleration between points 1 and 2.
            Instantaneous acceleration at 2:
            x-component [XXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            y-component [XXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            Average acceleration between points 1 and 2:
            x-component [XXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            y-component [XXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
          • Translational Dynamics
            DT1A57272Suppose a car stopped on the road is hit from behind
            by a bus so that it accelerates up to 4.47 m/s (10.0 mph)
            in 0.100 s.

            If the driver of the car has a mass of 50.0 kg, what average
            net force is exerted on her during the crash?
            Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            DT1B37276An F-14A jet with a mass of 32,000 kg has a typical lift-off
            distance of 900 m and a corresponding liftoff speed of
            70.0 m/s.

            Assuming its acceleration is constant, calculate the average
            net force on the jet in newtons. Ignore the effect of friction
            and air drag.
            Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            DT3A41888Suppose a 0.006 kg bullet traveling at 100.0 m/s strikes
            a bulletproof vest and comes to a rest in about 0.005 s.

            What average force does the bullet exert on the vest?
            Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            DT3B428.554A modern nuclear aircraft carrier has a mass of around
            9.0e7 kg and is capable of traveling in excess of 30.0 knots
            (15.4 m/s).

            Suppose one of these giants plowed into a pier at 30.0 knots,
            coming to rest in 30.0 seconds, what average force would the
            carrier exert on the pier?
            Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            DT3CA car travelling at 10.0 m/s is involved in a head-on crash. The driver,
            whose mass is 60.0 kg, is to be brought to rest within the
            passenger compartment by uniformly compressing an
            inflated air bag through a distance of 0.30 m.

            Find the average force exerted on the air bag by the driver
            during the collision.
            Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]

            If we ignore friction and drag, what is the magnitude
            of the car's velocity when it hits the garage door?

            Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            DT9BA box slides a distance of 3.48 m down a plane which makes
            a 30.0 deg angle with the horizontal. The mass of the box is
            6.21 kg. The frictional force on the box is 13.1 N. What is
            the magnitude of the box's velocity when it reaches the
            bottom of the plane if it started from rest?

            Use Newton's laws to solve this problem.
            Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
          • Work and Energy
            WE6779.589.5A 58 kg box slides on a horizontal surface as shown below.
            When the box reaches p1, it is sliding at a speed of 3.7 m/s.
            At p1 the box slides onto a region that has friction and
            it slows to a stop in 5.2 m. Assuming the coefficient of
            kinetic friction between the box and the surface is constant,
            find the value of the coefficient.
            [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
          • Power
            POW6A103263A physics student decides to measure the power required for
            his 1900 kg car to maintain a constant speed of 24.6 m/s
            (55 mph) on level ground. To get the necessary data, he
            puts the car into neutral (coasting) and finds that during
            a period of 7.5 s, the speed drops from 25.7 m/s (57.5 mph)
            to 23.5 m/s (52.5 mph). Use these data to calculate
            the drag force acting on the car under while slowing down
            on level ground.
            [XXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            Now, use this result to find the power required from
            the car's engine to maintain the car at a constant speed
            of 24.6 m/s (55 mph).
            [XXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            Assume the car is moving to the right.
          • Linear Momentum
            IMP157877A 0.145 kg baseball pitched at 40 m/s is hit on
            a horizontal line back to the pitcher at 52 m/s.
            If the contact time of the ball with the bat is
            4.7e-3 s, calculate the magnitude of the average
            force acting on the ball due the bat.
            [XXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            Assume the batter is to the right of the pitcher.
          • Electric Field
            FOR11B85358A electron with a charge of -1.6e-19 C and a mass of
            9.11e-31 kg starts at rest in a region with a uniform
            electric field of 1500 N/C in the positive x direction.
            What will be the kinetic energy of the electron after it
            has been accelerated through a distance of 2.5 cm?
            Energy: [XXXXXXXXXXXX]
            In this problem, gravity can be ignored.
            FOR11C66969A electron with a charge of -1.6e-19 C and a mass of
            9.11e-31 kg starts at rest in a region with a uniform
            electric field of 1500 N/C in the positive x direction.
            What will be the kinetic energy of the electron after it
            has been accelerated for 15 ns?

            In this problem, gravity can be ignored.
            ELEC4B485.589A proton (qp = 1.60e-19 C; mp = 1.67e-27 kg) is in a region where
            there is a uniform electric field E of magnitude 320 N/C, directed
            along the positive x-axis. The proton accelerates from rest and
            reaches a speed of 1.20e+5 m/s. How long does it take the proton to
            reach this speed?
            Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXX]
            In this problem, gravity can be ignored.
            ELEC5B43988A proton (qp = 1.60e-19 C; mp = 1.67e-27 kg) is in a region where
            there is a uniform electric field E of magnitude 920 N/C, directed
            along the negative x-axis. The proton accelerates from rest and
            reaches a speed of 7.2e+3 m/s. How far does the proton travel
            during this duration?
            Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXX]
            In this problem, gravity can be ignored.
        • vf_y = vi_y + a(avg)_y*t 
          • Vectors
            VEC6A937.589At t = 0.00 s, a particle moving in the xy plane has a velocity
            of (3.00 i - 2.00 j) m/s at the origin. At t = 3.00 s, the particle's
            velocity is (9.00 i + 7.00 j) m/s.

            Find the average acceleration of the particle expressed in
            component form.
            Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX] i + [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX] j
            VEC6B39597At time t0, a particle moving in the xy plane has a velocity
            of (3.00 i + 4.00 j) m/s at the origin. At time t1 the particle's
            velocity is (- 1.00 i + 2.00 j) m/s. Its average acceleration
            over the time interval is (- 8.00 i - 4.00 j) m/s^2.

            Find the length of the time interval.
            Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            VEC6C44998At t = 0 s, a particle moving in the xy plane has a velocity
            of (4.00 i + 2.00 j) m/s at the origin. Its average acceleration
            over the next 3.00 s is (6.00 i + 7.00 j) m/s^2.

            Find the velocity of the particle at t=3.00 s expressed
            in component form.
            Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX] i + [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX] j
            VEC6D43998At t = 5.00 s, a particle moving in the xy plane has a velocity
            of (15.0 i + 18.0 j) m/s at the origin. Its average acceleration
            over the previous 5.00 s was (3.00 i + 2.00 j) m/s^2.

            Find the velocity of the particle at t = 0 s expressed in
            component form.
            Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX] i + [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX] j
            VEC8A51098An airplane is flying at 207 m/s in a direction of 57 deg with
            respect to the x-axis. The pilot receives instructions to change
            course. After a time interval of 145 s its velocity is 243 m/s
            in a direction of 324 deg with respect to the standard x-axis.
            Find the x and y components of the average acceleration during
            the change of course.

            acceleration during this time interval.

            KT12A64692A cannon is on the slope of a hill 100.0 m down the slope from
            a castle. The slope makes an angle of 13.0 deg with respect
            to the horizontal. If the cannon is pointed 40.0 deg above
            the horizontal and fires at the castle, what is the magnitude of
            the initial velocity if the cannonball is to hit the castle?

            Note: Assume the cannonball hits at the base of the castle wall.
            Ignore the effects if air resistance.
            Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            KT12B46439A cannon is on the slope of a hill 132.6 m down the slope from a
            castle. The slope makes an angle of 12.0 deg with respect to the
            horizontal. If the cannon is pointed 45.0 deg above the
            horizontal and hits the base of the castle wall, what will be the
            x and y components of the velocity of the cannonball as it hits
            the wall? HINT: Use a horizontal x axis.
            x-component: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            y-component: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            KT12C100059A cannon is on the slope of a hill 132.6 m down the slope from
            a castle. The slope makes an angle of 12.0 deg with respect
            to the horizontal. If the cannon is pointed 45.0 deg above
            the horizontal and has a muzzle velcity of 40.2 m/s, what will
            be the x and y components of the velocity of the cannonball as
            it hits the wall.
            x-component: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            y-component: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            Note that the x-component of the displacement of the cannonball
            during T0 to T1 is equal to the x-component of the relative
            position of the castle with respect to the cannon.
            KT13A469.550.5A boy is playing catch with himself by throwing a ball
            straight up. How fast does he throw the ball if it comes back
            to his hands a second later?

            At low speeds air friction is negligible.

            Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]

            FOR11A1063.548.5A fully ionized alpha particle with a charge of 3.20e-19 C
            and a mass of 6.64e-27 kg is initially moving in
            the x direction with a velocity of 1.50e+3 m/s. The particle
            enters a region where there is a uniform electric field in

            moved 0.500 m in the x direction?

            ELEC3B90159An electron (qe = -1.60e-19 C; me = 9.11e-31 kg) is in a region,
            between two parallel charged plates, that produce a uniform electric
            field E of magnitude 2.0e+4 N/C. The separation between the plates
            is 1.5 cm. The electron undergoes a constant acceleration from rest
            near the negative plate and passes through a tiny hole in the positive
            plate (see Figure below). Find the velocity of the electron as it leaves
            the hole.
            Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXX]
            In this problem, gravity can be ignored.
            ELEC6B1086.539An electron (qe = -1.60e-19 C; me = 9.11e-31 kg) is in a region near
            the surface of the earth where there is a uniform electric field E
            of magnitude 4.0e-12 N/C, directed along the negative y-axis.
            The electron is moving in the positive y-direction at an initial
            velocity of 4.3 m/s. How far will the electron travel before it
            momentarily comes to rest?
            Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXX]
            In this problem, please include gravity.
        • v_x^2 = v0_x^2 + 2*a_x*d_x  [a_x is constant]

            y-component: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            Note that the x-component of the displacement of the cannonball
            during T0 to T1 is equal to the x-component of the relative
            position of the castle with respect to the cannon.
            KT13A469.550.5A boy is playing catch with himself by throwing a ball
            straight up. How fast does he throw the ball if it comes back
            to his hands a second later?

            At low speeds air friction is negligible.

            Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            KT13B526.553.5A boy throws a ball straight up and 1.06 s later he
            catches it 10.0 cm below the point at which he released it.
            What was the initial velocity of the ball?

            Neglect air friction.

            0.80 m above the height from the point where it left his
            hand. The ball is moving downward a velocity of 10 m/s
            when it lands in his hand.
            What was the magnitude of the velocity of the ball
            when he threw it?

            How long was the ball in the air?
            [XXXXXXXXXXXXXX]

            Compute the average net force that acted on him as he
            plowed into the snow.

            trooper was 90.0 kg and his speed when he hit the snow
            was 20.0 m/s.

            ELEC3B90159An electron (qe = -1.60e-19 C; me = 9.11e-31 kg) is in a region,
            between two parallel charged plates, that produce a uniform electric
            field E of magnitude 2.0e+4 N/C. The separation between the plates
            is 1.5 cm. The electron undergoes a constant acceleration from rest
            near the negative plate and passes through a tiny hole in the positive
            plate (see Figure below). Find the velocity of the electron as it leaves
            the hole.
            Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXX]
            In this problem, gravity can be ignored.

            of magnitude 4.0e-12 N/C, directed along the negative y-axis.

            velocity of 4.3 m/s. How far will the electron travel before it
            momentarily comes to rest?
            Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXX]
            In this problem, please include gravity.

            the merry-go-round on the child.

          • Rotational Kinematics

            KR1CA wheel rotates counterclockwise at a constant angular
            velocity of 2.5 rad/s. How long does it take the wheel to
            rotate through an angle of 210 rad?
            answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]

          • Rotational Kinematics

            distance of a rim point from the axis of rotation.

            EROT31366.589.5As shown in the figure below, a hoop with a 0.25 m radius
            is at the bottom of a 20 deg incline and is headed up
            the incline with an initial velocity of 4.3 m/s.
            If the hoop rolls without slipping, what distance, d,
            will the hoop roll up the incline before it momentarily
            comes to rest?
            [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            Let the initial height of the hoop, measured at cm, be zero.
            Use the center of mass (cm) to describe the translational
            motion of the hoop.
            EROT44689A tire with a radius of 0.3 m, a mass of 10 kg and a moment
            of inertia of 0.5 kg*m^2 starts from rest at the top of a
            15 deg incline that is 5.2 m long. If the tire rolls without
            slipping, what will be the magnitude of the velocity of
            the tire when it reaches the bottom of the incline?
            [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            Let the initial height of the tire, measured at cm, be zero.
            Use the center of mass (cm) to describe the translational
            motion of the tire.

            DT10A249637Two blocks, one on top of the other, slide together down a
            frictionless plane inclined at 37.0 deg. The mass of the
            lower block (block 1) is 30.0 kg, and the mass of the top block
            (block 2) is 25.0 kg. Assume there is no friction between the
            two blocks. What is the magnitude of the acceleration of the
            top block?
            [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            What is the magnitude of the normal force acting on the top
            block due to the lower block?
            [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            Note: Compound bodies are not allowed in this problem.
            Newton's laws must be applied to individual bodies only.
            DT11A166853A 19.0 kg box and a 28.0 kg crate are in contact as they rest
            on an inclined plane which makes an angle of 18.0 deg
            with the horizontal. A mid applies a horizontal force to the
            crate, causing both the box and the crate to have an
            acceleration up the plane of 1.30 m/s^2.

            Find the magnitude of the horizontal force applied to the
            crate. Assume that the plane is frictionless.
            Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            Note: Compound bodies are not allowed in this problem.
            Newton's laws must be applied to individual bodies only.
            DT11B1525.533A 23.0 kg box and a 22.0 kg crate are in contact as they rest
            on an inclined plane which makes an angle of 15.0 deg
            with the horizontal. A mid applies a horizontal force to
            the crate, causing both the box and the crate to have an
            acceleration up the plane of 1.25 m/s^2.

            Assuming that the plane is frictionless, find the normal force
            exerted by the box on the crate and the normal force exerted
            by the plane on the box.
            Normal force by box on crate: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            Normal force by plane on box: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            Note: Compound bodies are not allowed in this problem.
            Newton's laws must be applied to individual bodies only.

            of 24.6 m/s (55 mph).

            DT12A59577A 90.0 kg astronaut is in a space shuttle 450 km above the

            magnitude of the acceleration of the astronaut.

            mass of Earth = 5.98e24 kg

            DT19A sky diver of mass 80.0 kg (including parachute) jumps off
            a plane and begins her descent. When the sky diver descends
            to a certain height from the ground, she deploys her
            parachute to ensure a safe landing. (Usually the parachute
            is deployed when the sky diver reaches an altitude of about
            900 m or 3000 feet.) Ignore any horizontal motion of
            the sky diver.

            For an object falling through air at a high speed v, the drag
            force acting on it due to air resistance can be expressed
            as F = K*v^2, where the coefficient K depends on the shape
            and size of the falling object and on the density of air.
            For a human body, K is roughly 0.25 kg/m. Use this value for
            K to find the magnitude of the terminal velocity of the sky
            diver before deploying the parachute.
            Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]






            When the parachute is fully open, the effective drag
            coefficient of the sky diver plus parachute increases to
            60.0 kg/m. Find the terminal speed of the sky diver after
            the parachute is opened.
            Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]

            FLUIDS1363785A scuba diver in full gear weighs 850 N. In order to make himself
            neutrally buoyant in fresh water he must add 8 kg of lead weights.

            of the lead weights, what is the average density of the scuba

            Assume the weights rest on the diver's back.

            FLUIDS14616.575A helium balloon has a volume of 1.57 m^3 when it is fully inflated.
            What is the maximum mass that can be supported by this balloon in air?
            The density of helium is 0.179 kg/m^3. The density of air is 1.29 kg/m^3.

            Take the mass of the balloon surface to be included as part of the
            supported mass, and treat the weight of the balloon itself as entirely
            due to the weight of the helium filling its volume. You may consider
            the balloon and mass as a compound body.
            Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]

            center. What is the magnitude of the force on the astronaut
            due to the Earth?
            [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            What is the value of the "acceleration due to gravity"
            g(r) = Fg(r)/m at this point? Note: assuming no other forces
            act on the astronaut, you can define this sought as the
            magnitude of the acceleration of the astronaut.
            [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            mass of Earth = 5.98e24 kg
            DT13B496.587.5A Cessna in level flight with constant horizontal velocity
            has a thrust of 650 N. The mass of the Cessna is 1200 kg.
            What is the magnitude of the drag force on the airplane?
            [XXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            What is magnitude of the lift force on the airplane?
            [XXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            Treat the lift force as an applied force due to the air.
            Assume the Cessna is traveling to the right.

            DT19A sky diver of mass 80.0 kg (including parachute) jumps off
            a plane and begins her descent. When the sky diver descends
            to a certain height from the ground, she deploys her
            parachute to ensure a safe landing. (Usually the parachute
            is deployed when the sky diver reaches an altitude of about
            900 m or 3000 feet.) Ignore any horizontal motion of
            the sky diver.

            For an object falling through air at a high speed v, the drag
            force acting on it due to air resistance can be expressed
            as F = K*v^2, where the coefficient K depends on the shape
            and size of the falling object and on the density of air.
            For a human body, K is roughly 0.25 kg/m. Use this value for
            K to find the magnitude of the terminal velocity of the sky
            diver before deploying the parachute.
            Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]






            When the parachute is fully open, the effective drag
            coefficient of the sky diver plus parachute increases to
            60.0 kg/m. Find the terminal speed of the sky diver after
            the parachute is opened.
            Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]

            the normal force on the car due to the road.

            FLUIDS14616.575A helium balloon has a volume of 1.57 m^3 when it is fully inflated.
            What is the maximum mass that can be supported by this balloon in air?
            The density of helium is 0.179 kg/m^3. The density of air is 1.29 kg/m^3.

            Take the mass of the balloon surface to be included as part of the
            supported mass, and treat the weight of the balloon itself as entirely
            due to the weight of the helium filling its volume. You may consider
            the balloon and mass as a compound body.
            Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]

            frictionless plane inclined at 37.0 deg. The mass of the
            lower block (block 1) is 30.0 kg, and the mass of the top block
            (block 2) is 25.0 kg. Assume there is no friction between the
            two blocks. What is the magnitude of the acceleration of the
            top block?
            [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            What is the magnitude of the normal force acting on the top
            block due to the lower block?
            [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            Note: Compound bodies are not allowed in this problem.
            Newton's laws must be applied to individual bodies only.
            DT11A166853A 19.0 kg box and a 28.0 kg crate are in contact as they rest
            on an inclined plane which makes an angle of 18.0 deg
            with the horizontal. A mid applies a horizontal force to the
            crate, causing both the box and the crate to have an
            acceleration up the plane of 1.30 m/s^2.

            Find the magnitude of the horizontal force applied to the
            crate. Assume that the plane is frictionless.
            Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            Note: Compound bodies are not allowed in this problem.
            Newton's laws must be applied to individual bodies only.
            DT11B1525.533A 23.0 kg box and a 22.0 kg crate are in contact as they rest
            on an inclined plane which makes an angle of 15.0 deg
            with the horizontal. A mid applies a horizontal force to
            the crate, causing both the box and the crate to have an
            acceleration up the plane of 1.25 m/s^2.

            Assuming that the plane is frictionless, find the normal force
            exerted by the box on the crate and the normal force exerted
            by the plane on the box.
            Normal force by box on crate: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            Normal force by plane on box: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            Note: Compound bodies are not allowed in this problem.
            Newton's laws must be applied to individual bodies only.
        • F12_y = - F21_y  Newton's Third law (components)
          • Statics
            S2B77177A dumpster of mass 984 kg sits on a hilly street that is inclined
            at 15 deg to the horizontal. Find the magnitude of the normal
            force on the dumpster due to the street. Due to friction, the
            dumpster remains at rest.
            Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            S2C48378.5A 87.3 kg skier is standing on a ski slope that makes an angle
            of 171 deg with the standard x-axis. Due to friction the skier is
            momentarily standing still. Find the magnitude of the normal
            force on the skier due to the slope.
            Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]

            mass 2.00 kg rests on the package.

            What is the magnitude of the normal force exerted on the
            package by the table?
            Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
          • Translational Dynamics
            DT10A249637Two blocks, one on top of the other, slide together down a
            frictionless plane inclined at 37.0 deg. The mass of the
            lower block (block 1) is 30.0 kg, and the mass of the top block

            DT12A59577A 90.0 kg astronaut is in a space shuttle 450 km above the
            surface of the Earth. Taking the radius of the Earth to be
            6.37e6 m, that puts the astronaut 6.82e6 m from the Earth's
            center. What is the magnitude of the force on the astronaut
            due to the Earth?
            [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            What is the value of the "acceleration due to gravity"
            g(r) = Fg(r)/m at this point? Note: assuming no other forces
            act on the astronaut, you can define this sought as the
            magnitude of the acceleration of the astronaut.
            [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            mass of Earth = 5.98e24 kg
          • Circular Motion
            ROTS8A68573A 200 kg satellite is in a stable circular orbit located 500 km above
            the surface of the Earth (mass 5.98e24 kg). Taking the radius of
            the Earth to be 6.37e6 m, that puts the satellite a distance of
            6.87e6 m from the center of the Earth.

            What is the magnitude of the orbital velocity of the satellite?
            [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            What is the period of the orbit?
            [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            ROTS8B428.577.5A satellite is in a stable circular orbit of radius r about the Earth.
            Find an expression for its orbital velocity in terms of r, the mass
            of the Earth, and the gravitational constant G.
            Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]

            Note: Because this problem does not ask for a numerical value, Andes'
            solve-for function cannot be used to derive the answer. You must do
            any necessary algebra yourself.
          • Fluids
            FLUIDS8907.549.5A 90 kg man standing on a 10 kg piston of radius 1.2 m is in equilibrium
            due to the pressure in the hydraulic fluid below the piston.
            What is the pressure in the fluid at the location of the piston?
            Do NOT neglect the effect of the atmospheric pressure.
            Hint: You may consider the compound body of man and piston.
            Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            FLUIDS1363785A scuba diver in full gear weighs 850 N. In order to make himself
            neutrally buoyant in fresh water he must add 8 kg of lead weights.
            The density of fresh water is 1000 kg/m^3 . Ignoring the volume
            of the lead weights, what is the average density of the scuba
            diver and his gear?
            Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            Take 'diver' to mean the diver together with his gear.
            Assume the weights rest on the diver's back.
            Hint: consider the compound body of diver and weights.
            FLUIDS14616.575A helium balloon has a volume of 1.57 m^3 when it is fully inflated.
            What is the maximum mass that can be supported by this balloon in air?
            The density of helium is 0.179 kg/m^3. The density of air is 1.29 kg/m^3.

            Take the mass of the balloon surface to be included as part of the
            supported mass, and treat the weight of the balloon itself as entirely
            due to the weight of the helium filling its volume. You may consider
            the balloon and mass as a compound body.
            Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            FLUIDS1549369Ice has a density of 917 kg/m^3. The density of seawater is 1025 kg/m^3.
            To determine the percentage of the volume that is submerged whenever ice
            floats on seawater, consider a floating chunk of ice with a total volume
            of 100 m^3 and find the volume of the submerged portion of this chunk.

            Hint: Represent the chunk as a compound body composed of ice_submerged
            and ice_above_water.
            Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]

            EGRAV1A space probe orbits around the earth in a stable circular
            orbit of radius r from the earth's center.
            Find the total mechanical energy of the space probe as
            as a function of the masses and r.
            total mechanical energy: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            Note: Because this problem does not ask for a numerical value,
            you must do any necessary algebra yourself.

            Next, find the minimum work the rocket boosters on the probe
            must do so that the probe completely escapes the earth's
            gravitational field. Express your answer in terms of
            the masses and r.
            Work: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            Ignore any change of mass of the space probe.
      • Rotational
        • 0 = $t1_z + $t2_z + ...  rotational form of Newton's 2nd law ($a =0)
          • Statics
            S13Consider the uniform beam held in place by the wall and
            wire (at right_end) as shown in the figure below. There is
            a pivot point at the left end (left_end) of the beam. Recall
            that the weight of the beam itself acts on the midpoint (cm)
            of the beam.

            Calculate the magnitude of the tension in the wire. Express
            your answers in terms of the mass of the beam and g.
            Magnitude [XXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            Calculate the force exerted on the left end of the beam
            (left_end) by the wall. (Define this to be an "applied force.")
            x-component [XXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            y-component [XXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            S14An irregular shaped object lies on a board that is 1.58 m
            long. The board is supported by two scales, one at each end
            as shown in the figure. Scale A, the scale at the left end
            of the board, reads 183 N and scale B, the scale at the right
            end of the board, reads 151 N. What is the x-component of
            the position of the center of mass of the object (and board)
            relative to the left end of the board (left_end)?

            x-component [XXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            Use the left end of the board as the pivot point.
          • Rotational Dynamics
            DR8A813.572A horizontal uniform beam of mass 12.4 kg is 2.7 m long. It is
            pivoted at a point 1.2 m from the left end. A crate hangs by a
            rope from the beam, giving rise to a tension force of 19.8 N
            acting at the right hand end. What downward force must be
            applied at the left hand end in order for the beam to be in
            rotational equilibrium?
            [XXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            Note: do not neglect the weight of the beam itself which acts
            on the midpoint (cm) of the beam.
        • $tnet_z = I*$a_z  rotational form of Newton's 2nd law
          • Rotational Dynamics
            DR6A417.581.5A flywheel has a radius of 0.450 m, and is mounted on friction-
            less bearings on a horizontal shaft through its center. A cord
            is wrapped around the rim of the wheel and a steady pull of
            45.0 N is exerted on the cord.

            If the moment of inertia of the wheel is 4.00 kg.m^2, what is
            the magnitude of the angular acceleration of the wheel?
            Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            Note: treat the force the cord exerts on the rim-pt as an
            "applied" force for the purposes of this problem.

            its center. There are three forces: 21.0 N applied at an angle
            of 30 deg to the top left corner, 18.0 N applied at an angle
            of 100 deg to the top right corner, and 24.0 N applied upward
            to the bottom right corner.

            Calculate the z component of the angular acceleration
            about this axis.
            Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]

            DR2A66375.5A 5.00 m bar lies along the x-axis. It experiences a 7.50 N
            force straight down at its right-hand end, and a 13.2 N force
            up and to the left at 30 deg above the horizontal, at a
            point P1 located 2.00 m from its left-hand end.

            What is the z-component of the net torque on the bar
            about its left-hand end?
            Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            DR2B491.583A 4.50 m bar lies along the x-axis. It experiences a 6.25 N
            force straight up at its left-hand end, and a 40.0 N force
            up and to the left at 30 deg above the horizontal, at a
            point 1.50 m from its left-hand end.

            What is the z-component of the net torque on the bar about
            its right-hand end?

            Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            DR3A78983A 5.00 m bar at 50 deg above horizontal experiences an
            8.50 N force straight down at its right-hand end. It also
            experiences a 12.0 N force at 150 deg ccw from the
            standard x-axis, at point p1 that is 1.50 m from its left end.

            What is the z-component of the resultant torque on the bar
            about its left end?
            Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            DR4A71478A square metal plate 0.180 m on each side lies in the x-y plane
            and is pivoted about the z-axis through its center. Calculate
            the z-component of the net torque about this axis due to three
            forces: 16.0 N down, applied to top left corner, 24.0 N down,
            applied to the top right corner, and 18.0 N, applied at 45 deg
            to the bottom right corner.
            Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            DR5A94561A square metal plate 0.18 m on each side lies in the x-y
            plane and is pivoted about the z-axis through its center.
            The net torque on the plate is 5.88 N.m in the positive z-
            direction, and is due to three forces: a downward force of
            unknown magnitude applied to the top left corner, a force of
            24.0 N down applied to the top right corner, and a force of
            18.0 N, applied at 45 deg ccw from the standard x-axis, to
            the bottom right corner.

            What is the magnitude of the force applied to the top left
            corner?
            Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]

        • $t_x = r_y*F_z - r_z*F_y  torque defined (x component)
        • $t_y = r_z*F_x - r_x*F_z  torque defined (y component)
        • $t_z = r*F*sin($qF-$qr)) or $t_z = r_x*F_y - r_y*F_x  torque defined (z component)
          • Statics
