            lies in the x-y plane and is pivoted about the z-axis through
            its center. There are three forces: 21.0 N applied at an angle
            of 30 deg to the top left corner, 18.0 N applied at an angle
            of 100 deg to the top right corner, and 24.0 N applied upward
            to the bottom right corner.

            Calculate the z component of the angular acceleration
            about this axis.
            Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            DR8A813.572A horizontal uniform beam of mass 12.4 kg is 2.7 m long. It is
            pivoted at a point 1.2 m from the left end. A crate hangs by a
            rope from the beam, giving rise to a tension force of 19.8 N
            acting at the right hand end. What downward force must be
            applied at the left hand end in order for the beam to be in
            rotational equilibrium?
            [XXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            Note: do not neglect the weight of the beam itself which acts
            on the midpoint (cm) of the beam.
    • Work Energy and Power
      • W = F*d*cos($q) or W = F_x*d_x + F_y*d_y  work defined
        • Work and Energy
          WEQ5Suppose a 2000 kg truck is dropped from a certain height
          above the ground, starting from rest. Find the height from
          which it is dropped if it strikes the ground at 22.35 m/s.
          Neglect air resistance. Assume that the origin is at
          the ground.
          [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
          Use energy methods to solve this problem.
          E1A23898A man pushes a 20.0 kg crate across a frictionless floor with
          a horizontal force of 24.0 N. What work is done by the man
          on the crate in displacing it by 5.00 m?
          Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
          E1B29296A woman pulls a suitcase with a strap which makes an angle
          of 37.0 deg with the horizontal. The suitcase has a mass
          of 15.0 kg, and has wheels on it so that it can be considered
          to move without friction. If the tension in the strap is 80.0 N,
          what work is done on the suitcase by the strap when it is
          displaced 2.50 m horizontally?
          [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
          E1C27196A boy pushes a shopping cart with a downward force of
          100 N at 30.0 deg below the horizontal. If his little
          brother pushes horizontally backwards with a force of 20.0 N,
          what is the net work done on the shopping cart in moving it
          15.0 m? Ignore the effects of friction on the shopping cart.
          Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
          E2A48988A girl pushes a cart up the full length of a 10.0 deg incline
          with a horizontal force of 50.0 N. If the length of the incline
          is 8.00 m, what work was done on the cart by the girl?
          [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]

          If the mass of the cart is 20.0 kg, what work was done
          on the cart by gravity?
          [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
          E2B32798A boy pushes a cart up a 7.00 deg incline with a force
          of 47.0 N directed downward at 10.0 deg below the
          horizontal.
          If the length of the incline is 12.0 m, what work was done
          on the cart by the boy?
          Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
          E2C75095A man pushes a shopping cart of total mass 55.0 kg up a 5.00
          deg ramp. He pushes the cart with a downward force of
          130 N at 20.0 deg below the horizontal. If his son pushes
          backwards on the cart with a force of 8.00 N down the slope,
          what is the net work done on the shopping cart in moving it
          22.0 m? Ignore the effects of friction on the shopping cart.
          Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
          E3A29297A tourist rides at constant speed in the elevator of the
          Empire State Building. Including his camera bag, he
          has a total mass of 96.4 kg. If he starts at street level
          and rides the elevator to the 86th floor observation deck, which
          is at a height of 320 m above ground level, what is the work done on
          the tourist by the elevator?
          Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
          E8A828.579.5A person pulls an 18.3 kg box across a floor by pulling on a
          rope with a constant force of 50.0 N. The rope is horizontal.
          The frictional force on the box is 44.8 N. Determine the
          magnitude of the velocity of the box after it has been
          pulled 5.00 m starting from rest.

          Use work energy concepts. Solutions using other methods
          will not be recognized. You may take the floor to be the
          zero level of gravitational potential energy.
          Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
          E8B671.587A person pulls an 16.5 kg box across a floor by pulling on a
          rope with a constant force of 47.5 N. The rope is horizontal.
          The frictional force on the box is 42.0 N. Determine the
          magnitude of the velocity of the box after it has been pulled
          6.50 m starting from an initial velocity of 1.18 m/s.

          Use work energy concepts. Solutions using other methods
          will not be recognized. You may take the floor to be the
          zero level of gravitational potential energy.
          Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
          E9A636.587.5A box slides a distance of 3.48 m down a plane which makes
          a 30.0 deg angle with the horizontal. The mass of the box is
          6.21 kg. The frictional force on the box is 13.1 N. What is
          the magnitude of the box's velocity when it reaches the
          bottom of the plane if it started from rest?

          Use work energy concepts. Solutions using other methods
          will not be recognized. You may take the zero level of
          gravitational potential energy to be the bottom of the plane.
          Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
          E9B73384A box slides a distance of 4.21 m down a plane which makes
          a 30.0 deg angle with the horizontal. The mass of the box is
          5.70 kg. The frictional force on the box is 12.9 N. What is
          the magnitude of the velocity of the box when it reaches the
          bottom of the plane if it started at a velocity of 1.32 m/s?

          Use work energy concepts. Solutions using other methods
          will not be recognized. You may take the zero level of
          gravitational potential energy to be the bottom of the plane.
          Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
          E10A50789A box slides across a desk starting from a velocity of
          3.28 m/s and comes to rest in a distance of 2.63 m. If
          the box has a mass of 8.13 kg, what is the frictional force
          exerted by the desk on the box?

          Use work energy concepts. Solutions using other methods
          will not be recognized. You may take the desktop to be
          the zero level of gravitational potential energy.
          Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
          E11A51092A ship which has a constant thrust of 1.65e4 N accelerates
          from rest and reaches a velocity of 4.32 m/s in 60.0 m. The mass
          of the ship is 7.00e4 kg. What is the work done by drag?
          Use work energy concepts. Solutions using other methods
          will not be recognized.

          Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
          Note: Neglect forces in the vertical direction. Treat thrust as
          an applied force due to the engine.
          WE1A11199A 35 kg crate is gently dropped off of the end of a platform
          that is 2.0 m above the ground. How much work is done on
          the crate by gravity during the crate's fall to the ground?
          [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
          WE2A30499A 100 kg box that is initially moving at 3.0 m/s to
          the right along a frictionless horizontal surface,
          as shown below, is pushed by a horizontal force of 40 N
          for a distance of 20 m. What is the magnitude of
          the velocity of the box at the end of the 20 m push?
          [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
          WE3A38499A 55 kg box is projected up an inclined plane with
          an initial speed of 5 m/s. If the height of the plane
          is 0.5 m and the incline is frictionless, what will be
          the speed of the box when it gets to the top of the plane?
          [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
          Choose the zero of gravitational potential energy at
          the bottom of the incline.
          WE4A53183A 80 kg box, that is initially sliding with a speed of 4 m/s,
          slides 6 m along a horizontal surface before reaching the top
          of a frictionless incline. While sliding on the horizontal
          surface the box experiences a constant frictional force of
          58.2 N. What will be the speed of the box when it reaches
          the flat frictionless surface at the bottom of the incline
          which is 0.4 m high?
          [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
          Choose the zero of gravitational potential energy to
          be at the bottom of the incline.
          WE5317.577.5A 20 kg box, that is initially sliding with a speed of 6 m/s,
          slides 5 m along a horizontal surface and then up
          a frictionless incline that is 0.5 m high. If the box
          experiences a constant frictional force of 39.2 N while
          on the bottom horizontal surface, what will be its speed when
          it reaches the top of the incline?
          [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
          Choose the zero of gravitational potential energy to be
          at the bottom of the incline.
          WE6779.589.5A 58 kg box slides on a horizontal surface as shown below.
          When the box reaches p1, it is sliding at a speed of 3.7 m/s.
          At p1 the box slides onto a region that has friction and
          it slows to a stop in 5.2 m. Assuming the coefficient of
          kinetic friction between the box and the surface is constant,
          find the value of the coefficient.
          [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
        • Power
          POW2A36884A coffee filter with a mass of 2.00 g falling at terminal velocity
          falls 1.00 m in 1.83 s. What is the net average power supplied
          to the coffee filter by all forces during this 1.83 s?
          Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
          POW5A1205.557What average power output from the car's engine is required for
          a 1200 kg car to climb a 2.00 km long 11.0 deg hill in 100 s?
          Assume the only retarding force is an air drag force with a
          magnitude of 700 N and that the speed of the car is constant.
          Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
        • Electric Field
          FOR11B85358A electron with a charge of -1.6e-19 C and a mass of
          9.11e-31 kg starts at rest in a region with a uniform
          electric field of 1500 N/C in the positive x direction.
          What will be the kinetic energy of the electron after it
          has been accelerated through a distance of 2.5 cm?
          Energy: [XXXXXXXXXXXX]
          In this problem, gravity can be ignored.
          FOR11C66969A electron with a charge of -1.6e-19 C and a mass of
          9.11e-31 kg starts at rest in a region with a uniform
          electric field of 1500 N/C in the positive x direction.
          What will be the kinetic energy of the electron after it
          has been accelerated for 15 ns?
          Energy: [XXXXXXXXXXXX]
          In this problem, gravity can be ignored.
          ELEC3B90159An electron (qe = -1.60e-19 C; me = 9.11e-31 kg) is in a region,
          between two parallel charged plates, that produce a uniform electric
          field E of magnitude 2.0e+4 N/C. The separation between the plates
          is 1.5 cm. The electron undergoes a constant acceleration from rest
          near the negative plate and passes through a tiny hole in the positive
          plate (see Figure below). Find the velocity of the electron as it leaves
          the hole.
          Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXX]
          In this problem, gravity can be ignored.
          ELEC4B485.589A proton (qp = 1.60e-19 C; mp = 1.67e-27 kg) is in a region where
          there is a uniform electric field E of magnitude 320 N/C, directed
          along the positive x-axis. The proton accelerates from rest and
          reaches a speed of 1.20e+5 m/s. How long does it take the proton to
          reach this speed?
          Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXX]
          In this problem, gravity can be ignored.
          ELEC5B43988A proton (qp = 1.60e-19 C; mp = 1.67e-27 kg) is in a region where
          there is a uniform electric field E of magnitude 920 N/C, directed
          along the negative x-axis. The proton accelerates from rest and
          reaches a speed of 7.2e+3 m/s. How far does the proton travel
          during this duration?
          Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXX]
          In this problem, gravity can be ignored.
          ELEC6B1086.539An electron (qe = -1.60e-19 C; me = 9.11e-31 kg) is in a region near
          the surface of the earth where there is a uniform electric field E
          of magnitude 4.0e-12 N/C, directed along the negative y-axis.
          The electron is moving in the positive y-direction at an initial
          velocity of 4.3 m/s. How far will the electron travel before it
          momentarily comes to rest?
          Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXX]
          In this problem, please include gravity.
      • Wnet = WF1 + WF2 + ...  net work defined
        • Work and Energy

          the ground.

          EGRAV1A space probe orbits around the earth in a stable circular
          orbit of radius r from the earth's center.
          Find the total mechanical energy of the space probe as
          as a function of the masses and r.
          total mechanical energy: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
          Note: Because this problem does not ask for a numerical value,
          you must do any necessary algebra yourself.

          Next, find the minimum work the rocket boosters on the probe
          must do so that the probe completely escapes the earth's
          gravitational field. Express your answer in terms of
          the masses and r.
          Work: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
          Ignore any change of mass of the space probe.
        • Power
          POW1B372.592What is the power required for an engine to accelerate a
          1500 kg car from rest to 30.0 m/s in 5.41 s?
          Neglect any frictional forces.
          Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
          POW2A36884A coffee filter with a mass of 2.00 g falling at terminal velocity
          falls 1.00 m in 1.83 s. What is the net average power supplied
          to the coffee filter by all forces during this 1.83 s?
          Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
          POW4A86968A mass is attached to a spring with a spring constant of 45.0 N/m
          and the mass is displaced 0.300 m from its equilibrium position.
          The mass is released from rest and passes through the
          equilibrium position in 0.280 s.

          What is the average power delivered to the mass by the spring
          during this time period? Assume friction is negligible.
          Neglect forces acting in the vertical direction.
          Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
          POW4B93073A mass is attached to a spring which has a spring constant of 50.0 N/m
          and the spring is compressed 0.450 m from its equilibrium position.
          The mass is released from rest and passes through the equilibrium
          position 0.440 s later.
          What is the average power delivered to the mass by the spring
          during this time period? Assume friction is negligible.
          Neglect forces acting in the vertical direction.
          Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
          POW5A1205.557What average power output from the car's engine is required for
          a 1200 kg car to climb a 2.00 km long 11.0 deg hill in 100 s?
          Assume the only retarding force is an air drag force with a
          magnitude of 700 N and that the speed of the car is constant.
          Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]

          WE5317.577.5A 20 kg box, that is initially sliding with a speed of 6 m/s,
          slides 5 m along a horizontal surface and then up
          a frictionless incline that is 0.5 m high. If the box
          experiences a constant frictional force of 39.2 N while
          on the bottom horizontal surface, what will be its speed when
          it reaches the top of the incline?
          [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
          Choose the zero of gravitational potential energy to be
          at the bottom of the incline.
          EGRAV1A space probe orbits around the earth in a stable circular
          orbit of radius r from the earth's center.
          Find the total mechanical energy of the space probe as
          as a function of the masses and r.
          total mechanical energy: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
          Note: Because this problem does not ask for a numerical value,
          you must do any necessary algebra yourself.

          Next, find the minimum work the rocket boosters on the probe
          must do so that the probe completely escapes the earth's
          gravitational field. Express your answer in terms of
          the masses and r.
          Work: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
          Ignore any change of mass of the space probe.
        • Power
          POW1B372.592What is the power required for an engine to accelerate a
          1500 kg car from rest to 30.0 m/s in 5.41 s?
          Neglect any frictional forces.
          Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
          POW2A36884A coffee filter with a mass of 2.00 g falling at terminal velocity
          falls 1.00 m in 1.83 s. What is the net average power supplied
          to the coffee filter by all forces during this 1.83 s?
          Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
          POW4A86968A mass is attached to a spring with a spring constant of 45.0 N/m
          and the mass is displaced 0.300 m from its equilibrium position.
          The mass is released from rest and passes through the
          equilibrium position in 0.280 s.

          What is the average power delivered to the mass by the spring
          during this time period? Assume friction is negligible.
          Neglect forces acting in the vertical direction.
          Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
          POW4B93073A mass is attached to a spring which has a spring constant of 50.0 N/m
          and the spring is compressed 0.450 m from its equilibrium position.
          The mass is released from rest and passes through the equilibrium
          position 0.440 s later.
          What is the average power delivered to the mass by the spring
          during this time period? Assume friction is negligible.
          Neglect forces acting in the vertical direction.
          Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
          POW5A1205.557What average power output from the car's engine is required for
          a 1200 kg car to climb a 2.00 km long 11.0 deg hill in 100 s?
          Assume the only retarding force is an air drag force with a
          magnitude of 700 N and that the speed of the car is constant.
          Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
      • Wnet = Kf - Ki  work-energy theorem
        • Work and Energy
          WEQ5Suppose a 2000 kg truck is dropped from a certain height
          above the ground, starting from rest. Find the height from
          which it is dropped if it strikes the ground at 22.35 m/s.
          Neglect air resistance. Assume that the origin is at
          the ground.
          [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
          Use energy methods to solve this problem.
          E8A828.579.5A person pulls an 18.3 kg box across a floor by pulling on a
          rope with a constant force of 50.0 N. The rope is horizontal.
          The frictional force on the box is 44.8 N. Determine the
          magnitude of the velocity of the box after it has been
          pulled 5.00 m starting from rest.

          Use work energy concepts. Solutions using other methods
          will not be recognized. You may take the floor to be the
          zero level of gravitational potential energy.
          Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
          E8B671.587A person pulls an 16.5 kg box across a floor by pulling on a
          rope with a constant force of 47.5 N. The rope is horizontal.
          The frictional force on the box is 42.0 N. Determine the
          magnitude of the velocity of the box after it has been pulled
          6.50 m starting from an initial velocity of 1.18 m/s.

          Use work energy concepts. Solutions using other methods
          will not be recognized. You may take the floor to be the
          zero level of gravitational potential energy.
          Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
          E9A636.587.5A box slides a distance of 3.48 m down a plane which makes
          a 30.0 deg angle with the horizontal. The mass of the box is
          6.21 kg. The frictional force on the box is 13.1 N. What is
          the magnitude of the box's velocity when it reaches the
          bottom of the plane if it started from rest?

          Use work energy concepts. Solutions using other methods
          will not be recognized. You may take the zero level of
          gravitational potential energy to be the bottom of the plane.
          Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
          E9B73384A box slides a distance of 4.21 m down a plane which makes
          a 30.0 deg angle with the horizontal. The mass of the box is
          5.70 kg. The frictional force on the box is 12.9 N. What is
          the magnitude of the velocity of the box when it reaches the
          bottom of the plane if it started at a velocity of 1.32 m/s?

          Use work energy concepts. Solutions using other methods
          will not be recognized. You may take the zero level of
          gravitational potential energy to be the bottom of the plane.
          Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
          E10A50789A box slides across a desk starting from a velocity of
          3.28 m/s and comes to rest in a distance of 2.63 m. If
          the box has a mass of 8.13 kg, what is the frictional force
          exerted by the desk on the box?

          Use work energy concepts. Solutions using other methods
          will not be recognized. You may take the desktop to be
          the zero level of gravitational potential energy.
          Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
          E11A51092A ship which has a constant thrust of 1.65e4 N accelerates
          from rest and reaches a velocity of 4.32 m/s in 60.0 m. The mass
          of the ship is 7.00e4 kg. What is the work done by drag?
          Use work energy concepts. Solutions using other methods
          will not be recognized.

          Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
          Note: Neglect forces in the vertical direction. Treat thrust as
          an applied force due to the engine.

          the right along a frictionless horizontal surface,
          as shown below, is pushed by a horizontal force of 40 N
          for a distance of 20 m. What is the magnitude of
          the velocity of the box at the end of the 20 m push?
          [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]

          is 0.5 m and the incline is frictionless, what will be
          the speed of the box when it gets to the top of the plane?
          [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
          Choose the zero of gravitational potential energy at
          the bottom of the incline.
          WE4A53183A 80 kg box, that is initially sliding with a speed of 4 m/s,
          slides 6 m along a horizontal surface before reaching the top
          of a frictionless incline. While sliding on the horizontal
          surface the box experiences a constant frictional force of
          58.2 N. What will be the speed of the box when it reaches
          the flat frictionless surface at the bottom of the incline
          which is 0.4 m high?
          [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
          Choose the zero of gravitational potential energy to
          be at the bottom of the incline.

        • Electric Field
          FOR11B85358A electron with a charge of -1.6e-19 C and a mass of
          9.11e-31 kg starts at rest in a region with a uniform
          electric field of 1500 N/C in the positive x direction.
          What will be the kinetic energy of the electron after it
          has been accelerated through a distance of 2.5 cm?
          Energy: [XXXXXXXXXXXX]
          In this problem, gravity can be ignored.
          FOR11C66969A electron with a charge of -1.6e-19 C and a mass of
          9.11e-31 kg starts at rest in a region with a uniform
          electric field of 1500 N/C in the positive x direction.
          What will be the kinetic energy of the electron after it
          has been accelerated for 15 ns?
          Energy: [XXXXXXXXXXXX]
          In this problem, gravity can be ignored.
          ELEC3B90159An electron (qe = -1.60e-19 C; me = 9.11e-31 kg) is in a region,
          between two parallel charged plates, that produce a uniform electric
          field E of magnitude 2.0e+4 N/C. The separation between the plates
          is 1.5 cm. The electron undergoes a constant acceleration from rest
          near the negative plate and passes through a tiny hole in the positive
          plate (see Figure below). Find the velocity of the electron as it leaves
          the hole.
          Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXX]
          In this problem, gravity can be ignored.
          ELEC4B485.589A proton (qp = 1.60e-19 C; mp = 1.67e-27 kg) is in a region where
          there is a uniform electric field E of magnitude 320 N/C, directed
          along the positive x-axis. The proton accelerates from rest and
          reaches a speed of 1.20e+5 m/s. How long does it take the proton to
          reach this speed?
          Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXX]
          In this problem, gravity can be ignored.
          ELEC5B43988A proton (qp = 1.60e-19 C; mp = 1.67e-27 kg) is in a region where
          there is a uniform electric field E of magnitude 920 N/C, directed
          along the negative x-axis. The proton accelerates from rest and
          reaches a speed of 7.2e+3 m/s. How far does the proton travel
          during this duration?
          Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXX]
          In this problem, gravity can be ignored.
          ELEC6B1086.539An electron (qe = -1.60e-19 C; me = 9.11e-31 kg) is in a region near
          the surface of the earth where there is a uniform electric field E
          of magnitude 4.0e-12 N/C, directed along the negative y-axis.
          The electron is moving in the positive y-direction at an initial
          velocity of 4.3 m/s. How far will the electron travel before it
          momentarily comes to rest?
          Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXX]
          In this problem, please include gravity.
      • ME = KE + $S Ui  mechanical energy defined
        • Work and Energy
          WEQ4A 0.6 kg rock in space has a velocity of magnitude 2.0 m/s
          at point A and kinetic energy of 7.50 J at point B.
          What is the net work done on the rock as it moves from A to B?

          Neglect air resistance. Assume that the origin is at
          the ground.
          [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
          Use energy methods to solve this problem.
          E4A67377A 3.00 kg block is placed against a vertical spring compressed by
          0.200 m. The spring constant is 1960 N/m. After the spring is
          released, the block flies into the air.

          How high will the block go above the uncompressed spring?
          Choose the zero of the gravitational potential energy at the top
          of the uncompressed spring.
          Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
          E4B37995A 3.00 kg block is placed against a vertical spring compressed
          by 0.200 m. The spring constant is 1960 N/m. After the spring is
          released, the block flies into the air.

          Find the velocity of the block when it is 0.750 m above the
          uncompressed spring. Choose the zero of gravitational
          potential energy to be at the top of the uncompressed spring.
          Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]

          by 0.150 m. The spring constant is 2020 N/m. After the spring,
          is released, the block flies into the air.
          How high will the block go above the uncompressed spring?
          Choose the zero of the gravitational potential energy to be
          at the top of the uncompressed spring.
          Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
          E5A30494A frictionless roller-coaster car tops the first hill whose height
          is 25.0 m above the base of the roller coaster with a speed of
          3.00 m/s.

          What is the magnitude of the car's instantaneous velocity at the
          point when it reaches the base?

          of the roller-coaster.

          E5B236100A frictionless roller-coaster car tops the first hill whose height
          is 30.0 m above the base of the roller coaster with a speed of
          3.00 m/s.

          What is the magnitude of the instantaneous velocity at the
          apex of the next hill which has a height of 10.0 m?
          Choose the zero of gravitational potential energy at the
          base of the roller-coaster.
          Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
          E6A23899A hailstone falls from a cumulonimbus cloud at a height of
          9000 m starting from rest. Using energy methods, and
          assuming that the effect of air friction can be ignored, find
          the magnitude of the instantaneous velocity of the hailstone,
          just before it hits the ground. Take the ground to be the
          zero level of gravitational potential energy.
          Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
          E7A64788A spring is fixed at the top of a frictionless plane that makes
          a 40.0 deg angle with respect to the horizontal. A 1.50 kg block
          is initially 0.600 m from the end of the uncompressed spring which
          has a spring constant of 200 N/m. The block is projected up the
          plane with an initial velocity of 4.00 m/s.

          What is the velocity of the block at the instant it has compressed
          the spring 0.200 m? Choose the zero of gravitational potential
          energy at the initial position of the block.
          Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]

          that makes a 40.0 deg angle with respect to the horizontal.
          A 1.30 kg block is projected up the plane from an initial position
          that is 0.600 m from the end of the uncompressed spring.

          With what initial velocity must the block be projected up the
          plane if it is to stop momentarily when it has compressed the
          spring by 0.400 m?

          position of the block.

          passes through a pendulum bob of mass 700 g. The bullet has
          a final velocity of 150 m/s in the x-direction after passing
          through the pendulum bob. The pendulum bob is supported by
          a rigid rod that has a length l and negligible mass. What is
          the maximum value of l such that the pendulum bob will swing
          in a complete vertical circle. (You may assume that
          the pendulum bob does not lose any mass.)
          length: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
        • Rotational Dynamics
          EROT257283In the figure below, a uniform bar with a length of 1.2 m
          and a mass of 0.95 kg is pivoted about one end.
          Initially, the bar is hanging straight down, as shown
          below. What initial angular velocity must the bar have
          to reach a straight up position and still have
          an angular velocity of 0.42 rad/s?
          [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
          Let the initial height of the bar, measured at cm, be zero.
          EROT31366.589.5As shown in the figure below, a hoop with a 0.25 m radius
          is at the bottom of a 20 deg incline and is headed up
          the incline with an initial velocity of 4.3 m/s.
          If the hoop rolls without slipping, what distance, d,
          will the hoop roll up the incline before it momentarily
          comes to rest?
          [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
          Let the initial height of the hoop, measured at cm, be zero.
          Use the center of mass (cm) to describe the translational
          motion of the hoop.
          EROT44689A tire with a radius of 0.3 m, a mass of 10 kg and a moment
          of inertia of 0.5 kg*m^2 starts from rest at the top of a
          15 deg incline that is 5.2 m long. If the tire rolls without
          slipping, what will be the magnitude of the velocity of
          the tire when it reaches the bottom of the incline?
          [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
          Let the initial height of the tire, measured at cm, be zero.
          Use the center of mass (cm) to describe the translational
          motion of the tire.

          separated by 1.8 mm lies in a uniform external electric
          field of 4500 N/C in the positive x direction. How much
          work would be required to rotate this dipole from alignment
          with the external field to an angle of 43 degrees with
          respect to the field?
          work: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
          Note: Define the sought as the work done by all non-conservative
          forces.

          magnetic moment from being aligned in the same direction as
          a magnetic field to being aligned in a direction opposite
          to the magnetic field. Assume that the field has a magnitude
          of 1.7 T and is in the positive Y direction
          work: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
          Note: Define the sought as the work done by all
          non-conservative forces.
      • Wnc = ME2 - ME1  change in mechanical energy
        • Work and Energy
          WEQ4A 0.6 kg rock in space has a velocity of magnitude 2.0 m/s
          at point A and kinetic energy of 7.50 J at point B.
          What is the net work done on the rock as it moves from A to B?
          [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
          WEQ5Suppose a 2000 kg truck is dropped from a certain height
          above the ground, starting from rest. Find the height from
          which it is dropped if it strikes the ground at 22.35 m/s.
          Neglect air resistance. Assume that the origin is at
          the ground.
          [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
          Use energy methods to solve this problem.
          E8A828.579.5A person pulls an 18.3 kg box across a floor by pulling on a
          rope with a constant force of 50.0 N. The rope is horizontal.
          The frictional force on the box is 44.8 N. Determine the
          magnitude of the velocity of the box after it has been
          pulled 5.00 m starting from rest.

          Use work energy concepts. Solutions using other methods
          will not be recognized. You may take the floor to be the
          zero level of gravitational potential energy.
          Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
          E8B671.587A person pulls an 16.5 kg box across a floor by pulling on a
          rope with a constant force of 47.5 N. The rope is horizontal.
          The frictional force on the box is 42.0 N. Determine the
          magnitude of the velocity of the box after it has been pulled
          6.50 m starting from an initial velocity of 1.18 m/s.

          Use work energy concepts. Solutions using other methods
          will not be recognized. You may take the floor to be the
          zero level of gravitational potential energy.
          Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
          E9A636.587.5A box slides a distance of 3.48 m down a plane which makes
          a 30.0 deg angle with the horizontal. The mass of the box is
          6.21 kg. The frictional force on the box is 13.1 N. What is
          the magnitude of the box's velocity when it reaches the
          bottom of the plane if it started from rest?

          Use work energy concepts. Solutions using other methods
          will not be recognized. You may take the zero level of
          gravitational potential energy to be the bottom of the plane.
          Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
          E9B73384A box slides a distance of 4.21 m down a plane which makes
          a 30.0 deg angle with the horizontal. The mass of the box is
          5.70 kg. The frictional force on the box is 12.9 N. What is
          the magnitude of the velocity of the box when it reaches the
          bottom of the plane if it started at a velocity of 1.32 m/s?

          Use work energy concepts. Solutions using other methods
          will not be recognized. You may take the zero level of
          gravitational potential energy to be the bottom of the plane.
          Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
          E10A50789A box slides across a desk starting from a velocity of
          3.28 m/s and comes to rest in a distance of 2.63 m. If
          the box has a mass of 8.13 kg, what is the frictional force
          exerted by the desk on the box?

          Use work energy concepts. Solutions using other methods
          will not be recognized. You may take the desktop to be
          the zero level of gravitational potential energy.
          Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
          E11A51092A ship which has a constant thrust of 1.65e4 N accelerates
          from rest and reaches a velocity of 4.32 m/s in 60.0 m. The mass
          of the ship is 7.00e4 kg. What is the work done by drag?
          Use work energy concepts. Solutions using other methods
          will not be recognized.

          Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
          Note: Neglect forces in the vertical direction. Treat thrust as
          an applied force due to the engine.
          WE2A30499A 100 kg box that is initially moving at 3.0 m/s to
          the right along a frictionless horizontal surface,
          as shown below, is pushed by a horizontal force of 40 N
          for a distance of 20 m. What is the magnitude of
          the velocity of the box at the end of the 20 m push?
          [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
          WE3A38499A 55 kg box is projected up an inclined plane with
          an initial speed of 5 m/s. If the height of the plane
          is 0.5 m and the incline is frictionless, what will be
          the speed of the box when it gets to the top of the plane?
          [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
          Choose the zero of gravitational potential energy at
          the bottom of the incline.
          WE4A53183A 80 kg box, that is initially sliding with a speed of 4 m/s,
          slides 6 m along a horizontal surface before reaching the top
          of a frictionless incline. While sliding on the horizontal
          surface the box experiences a constant frictional force of
          58.2 N. What will be the speed of the box when it reaches
          the flat frictionless surface at the bottom of the incline
          which is 0.4 m high?
          [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
          Choose the zero of gravitational potential energy to
          be at the bottom of the incline.
          WE5317.577.5A 20 kg box, that is initially sliding with a speed of 6 m/s,
          slides 5 m along a horizontal surface and then up
          a frictionless incline that is 0.5 m high. If the box
          experiences a constant frictional force of 39.2 N while
          on the bottom horizontal surface, what will be its speed when
          it reaches the top of the incline?
          [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
          Choose the zero of gravitational potential energy to be
          at the bottom of the incline.
          EGRAV1A space probe orbits around the earth in a stable circular
          orbit of radius r from the earth's center.
          Find the total mechanical energy of the space probe as
          as a function of the masses and r.
          total mechanical energy: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
          Note: Because this problem does not ask for a numerical value,
          you must do any necessary algebra yourself.

          Next, find the minimum work the rocket boosters on the probe
          must do so that the probe completely escapes the earth's
          gravitational field. Express your answer in terms of
          the masses and r.
          Work: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
          Ignore any change of mass of the space probe.
        • Power
          POW1B372.592What is the power required for an engine to accelerate a
          1500 kg car from rest to 30.0 m/s in 5.41 s?
          Neglect any frictional forces.
          Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
          POW2A36884A coffee filter with a mass of 2.00 g falling at terminal velocity
          falls 1.00 m in 1.83 s. What is the net average power supplied
          to the coffee filter by all forces during this 1.83 s?
          Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
          POW4A86968A mass is attached to a spring with a spring constant of 45.0 N/m
          and the mass is displaced 0.300 m from its equilibrium position.
          The mass is released from rest and passes through the
          equilibrium position in 0.280 s.

          What is the average power delivered to the mass by the spring
          during this time period? Assume friction is negligible.
          Neglect forces acting in the vertical direction.
          Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
          POW4B93073A mass is attached to a spring which has a spring constant of 50.0 N/m
          and the spring is compressed 0.450 m from its equilibrium position.
          The mass is released from rest and passes through the equilibrium
          position 0.440 s later.
          What is the average power delivered to the mass by the spring
          during this time period? Assume friction is negligible.
          Neglect forces acting in the vertical direction.
          Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
          POW5A1205.557What average power output from the car's engine is required for
          a 1200 kg car to climb a 2.00 km long 11.0 deg hill in 100 s?
          Assume the only retarding force is an air drag force with a
          magnitude of 700 N and that the speed of the car is constant.
          Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
        • Electric Field
          DIP1B95443.5A dipole made of positive and negative charges of 2.3 nC
          separated by 1.8 mm lies in a uniform external electric
          field of 4500 N/C in the positive x direction. How much
          work would be required to rotate this dipole from alignment
          with the external field to an angle of 43 degrees with
          respect to the field?
          work: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
          Note: Define the sought as the work done by all non-conservative
          forces.
        • Electric Potential
          POT7523.554How much work is required to move a 2.3e-6 C charge from rest at a
          position p1 where the potential is -2.6 V to rest at a point p2
          where the potential is 7.6 V?
          Note: Define the sought as the work done by all non-conservative forces.
          Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
          POT827778How much work is required to move a -4.3e-6 C charge from rest at a
          position p1 where the potential is 10.6 V to rest at a point p2
          where the potential is -20.4 V?
          Note: Define the sought as the work done by all non-conservative forces.
          Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
        • Magnetic Field
          MAGDIP472261Consider an atom with a magnetic moment of $m = 9.27e-24 J/T.
          How much work is required to change the orientation of its
          magnetic moment from being aligned in the same direction as
          a magnetic field to being aligned in a direction opposite
          to the magnetic field. Assume that the field has a magnitude
          of 1.7 T and is in the positive Y direction
          work: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
          Note: Define the sought as the work done by all
          non-conservative forces.
      • ME1 = ME2  [Wnc=0] conservation of mechanical energy
        • Work and Energy
          WEQ5Suppose a 2000 kg truck is dropped from a certain height
          above the ground, starting from rest. Find the height from
          which it is dropped if it strikes the ground at 22.35 m/s.
          Neglect air resistance. Assume that the origin is at
          the ground.
          [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
          Use energy methods to solve this problem.
          E4A67377A 3.00 kg block is placed against a vertical spring compressed by
          0.200 m. The spring constant is 1960 N/m. After the spring is
          released, the block flies into the air.

          How high will the block go above the uncompressed spring?
          Choose the zero of the gravitational potential energy at the top
          of the uncompressed spring.
          Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
          E4B37995A 3.00 kg block is placed against a vertical spring compressed
          by 0.200 m. The spring constant is 1960 N/m. After the spring is
          released, the block flies into the air.

          Find the velocity of the block when it is 0.750 m above the
          uncompressed spring. Choose the zero of gravitational
          potential energy to be at the top of the uncompressed spring.
          Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
          E4C263.584.5A 2.50 kg block is placed against a vertical spring compressed
          by 0.150 m. The spring constant is 2020 N/m. After the spring,
          is released, the block flies into the air.
          How high will the block go above the uncompressed spring?
          Choose the zero of the gravitational potential energy to be
          at the top of the uncompressed spring.
          Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
          E5A30494A frictionless roller-coaster car tops the first hill whose height
          is 25.0 m above the base of the roller coaster with a speed of
          3.00 m/s.

          What is the magnitude of the car's instantaneous velocity at the
          point when it reaches the base?
          Choose the zero of gravitational potential energy at the base
          of the roller-coaster.
          Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
          E5B236100A frictionless roller-coaster car tops the first hill whose height
          is 30.0 m above the base of the roller coaster with a speed of
          3.00 m/s.

          What is the magnitude of the instantaneous velocity at the
          apex of the next hill which has a height of 10.0 m?
          Choose the zero of gravitational potential energy at the
          base of the roller-coaster.
          Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
          E6A23899A hailstone falls from a cumulonimbus cloud at a height of
          9000 m starting from rest. Using energy methods, and
          assuming that the effect of air friction can be ignored, find
          the magnitude of the instantaneous velocity of the hailstone,
          just before it hits the ground. Take the ground to be the
          zero level of gravitational potential energy.
          Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
          E7A64788A spring is fixed at the top of a frictionless plane that makes
          a 40.0 deg angle with respect to the horizontal. A 1.50 kg block
          is initially 0.600 m from the end of the uncompressed spring which
          has a spring constant of 200 N/m. The block is projected up the
          plane with an initial velocity of 4.00 m/s.

          What is the velocity of the block at the instant it has compressed
          the spring 0.200 m? Choose the zero of gravitational potential
          energy at the initial position of the block.
          Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
          E7B32791A spring (k = 200 N/m) is fixed at the top of a frictionless plane
          that makes a 40.0 deg angle with respect to the horizontal.
          A 1.30 kg block is projected up the plane from an initial position
          that is 0.600 m from the end of the uncompressed spring.

          With what initial velocity must the block be projected up the
          plane if it is to stop momentarily when it has compressed the
          spring by 0.400 m?
          Choose the zero of gravitational potential energy at the initial
          position of the block.
          Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
          WE3A38499A 55 kg box is projected up an inclined plane with
          an initial speed of 5 m/s. If the height of the plane
          is 0.5 m and the incline is frictionless, what will be
          the speed of the box when it gets to the top of the plane?
          [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
          Choose the zero of gravitational potential energy at
          the bottom of the incline.
          WE4A53183A 80 kg box, that is initially sliding with a speed of 4 m/s,
          slides 6 m along a horizontal surface before reaching the top
          of a frictionless incline. While sliding on the horizontal
          surface the box experiences a constant frictional force of
          58.2 N. What will be the speed of the box when it reaches
          the flat frictionless surface at the bottom of the incline
          which is 0.4 m high?
          [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
          Choose the zero of gravitational potential energy to
          be at the bottom of the incline.

          POW4A86968A mass is attached to a spring with a spring constant of 45.0 N/m
          and the mass is displaced 0.300 m from its equilibrium position.
          The mass is released from rest and passes through the
          equilibrium position in 0.280 s.

          What is the average power delivered to the mass by the spring
          during this time period? Assume friction is negligible.
          Neglect forces acting in the vertical direction.

        • Linear Momentum
          LMOM5127757A bullet of mass 30 g and velocity 300 m/s in the x-direction
          passes through a pendulum bob of mass 700 g. The bullet has
          a final velocity of 150 m/s in the x-direction after passing
          through the pendulum bob. The pendulum bob is supported by
          a rigid rod that has a length l and negligible mass. What is
          the maximum value of l such that the pendulum bob will swing
          in a complete vertical circle. (You may assume that
          the pendulum bob does not lose any mass.)
          length: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
        • Rotational Dynamics
          EROT257283In the figure below, a uniform bar with a length of 1.2 m
          and a mass of 0.95 kg is pivoted about one end.
          Initially, the bar is hanging straight down, as shown
          below. What initial angular velocity must the bar have
          to reach a straight up position and still have
          an angular velocity of 0.42 rad/s?
          [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
          Let the initial height of the bar, measured at cm, be zero.
          EROT31366.589.5As shown in the figure below, a hoop with a 0.25 m radius
          is at the bottom of a 20 deg incline and is headed up
          the incline with an initial velocity of 4.3 m/s.
          If the hoop rolls without slipping, what distance, d,
          will the hoop roll up the incline before it momentarily
          comes to rest?
          [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
          Let the initial height of the hoop, measured at cm, be zero.
          Use the center of mass (cm) to describe the translational
          motion of the hoop.
          EROT44689A tire with a radius of 0.3 m, a mass of 10 kg and a moment
          of inertia of 0.5 kg*m^2 starts from rest at the top of a
          15 deg incline that is 5.2 m long. If the tire rolls without
          slipping, what will be the magnitude of the velocity of
          the tire when it reaches the bottom of the incline?
          [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
          Let the initial height of the tire, measured at cm, be zero.
          Use the center of mass (cm) to describe the translational
          motion of the tire.

          the speed of the box when it gets to the top of the plane?
          [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
          Choose the zero of gravitational potential energy at
          the bottom of the incline.
          WE4A53183A 80 kg box, that is initially sliding with a speed of 4 m/s,
          slides 6 m along a horizontal surface before reaching the top
          of a frictionless incline. While sliding on the horizontal
          surface the box experiences a constant frictional force of
          58.2 N. What will be the speed of the box when it reaches
          the flat frictionless surface at the bottom of the incline
          which is 0.4 m high?
          [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
          Choose the zero of gravitational potential energy to
          be at the bottom of the incline.
          WE5317.577.5A 20 kg box, that is initially sliding with a speed of 6 m/s,
          slides 5 m along a horizontal surface and then up
          a frictionless incline that is 0.5 m high. If the box
          experiences a constant frictional force of 39.2 N while
          on the bottom horizontal surface, what will be its speed when
          it reaches the top of the incline?
          [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
          Choose the zero of gravitational potential energy to be
          at the bottom of the incline.
          WE6779.589.5A 58 kg box slides on a horizontal surface as shown below.
          When the box reaches p1, it is sliding at a speed of 3.7 m/s.
          At p1 the box slides onto a region that has friction and
          it slows to a stop in 5.2 m. Assuming the coefficient of
          kinetic friction between the box and the surface is constant,
          find the value of the coefficient.
          [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
          EGRAV1A space probe orbits around the earth in a stable circular
          orbit of radius r from the earth's center.
          Find the total mechanical energy of the space probe as
          as a function of the masses and r.
          total mechanical energy: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
          Note: Because this problem does not ask for a numerical value,
          you must do any necessary algebra yourself.

          Next, find the minimum work the rocket boosters on the probe
          must do so that the probe completely escapes the earth's
          gravitational field. Express your answer in terms of
          the masses and r.
          Work: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
          Ignore any change of mass of the space probe.

          POW4A86968A mass is attached to a spring with a spring constant of 45.0 N/m
          and the mass is displaced 0.300 m from its equilibrium position.
          The mass is released from rest and passes through the
          equilibrium position in 0.280 s.

          What is the average power delivered to the mass by the spring
          during this time period? Assume friction is negligible.
          Neglect forces acting in the vertical direction.

          LMOM3A139768A billiard ball is moving in the positive x direction when it hits
          a stationary ball of the same mass. The collision is elastic and
          after the collision, the second ball moves at 2.30 m/s at an angle
          of 30.0 deg to the original line of motion. Find the magnitude
          and direction of the velocity of the first ball after the collision.
          magnitude: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
          direction: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
          To solve this problem, you may need to do any necessary algebra
          yourself.
          LMOM5127757A bullet of mass 30 g and velocity 300 m/s in the x-direction
          passes through a pendulum bob of mass 700 g. The bullet has
          a final velocity of 150 m/s in the x-direction after passing
          through the pendulum bob. The pendulum bob is supported by
          a rigid rod that has a length l and negligible mass. What is
          the maximum value of l such that the pendulum bob will swing
          in a complete vertical circle. (You may assume that
          the pendulum bob does not lose any mass.)
          length: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
          LMOM6137967A space probe, mass 722 kg, is moving to the right at 15 km/s
          toward a planet, mass 1.02e26 kg. In the same reference frame
          the planet is moving at 7 km/s toward the probe. The probe
          makes an arc of 180 deg around the planet due to
          the gravitational force.
          After the probe moves away from the planet, how fast is it
          moving in the original reference frame?
          velocity (magnitude): [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
          LMOM7103264A block of mass m1 is sliding along a frictionless track.
          The original velocity of m1 is 3 m/s in the positive
          x-direction. There is a strong magnet in m1 with its
          north seeking pole pointed in the direction of its
          motion. Block m1 interacts with block m2 which was initially
          at rest. Block m2 has a similar strong magnet embedded within
          it with the north seeking pole pointed at m1.
          In this problem, the blocks never touch and it may be
          considered as a perfectly elastic collision in one dimension.

          For m1 = 3 kg and m2 = 5 kg, determine
          the x-component of the final velocity of each block.
          final v_x of m1: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
          final v_x of m2: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
        • Rotational Dynamics
          EROT31366.589.5As shown in the figure below, a hoop with a 0.25 m radius
          is at the bottom of a 20 deg incline and is headed up
          the incline with an initial velocity of 4.3 m/s.
          If the hoop rolls without slipping, what distance, d,
          will the hoop roll up the incline before it momentarily
          comes to rest?

          Use the center of mass (cm) to describe the translational
          motion of the hoop.

          between two parallel charged plates, that produce a uniform electric
          field E of magnitude 2.0e+4 N/C. The separation between the plates
          is 1.5 cm. The electron undergoes a constant acceleration from rest
          near the negative plate and passes through a tiny hole in the positive
          plate (see Figure below). Find the velocity of the electron as it leaves
          the hole.
          Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXX]

          magnitude of the velocity of the box after it has been
          pulled 5.00 m starting from rest.

          Use work energy concepts. Solutions using other methods
          will not be recognized. You may take the floor to be the
          zero level of gravitational potential energy.

          a 1200 kg car to climb a 2.00 km long 11.0 deg hill in 100 s?
          Assume the only retarding force is an air drag force with a
          magnitude of 700 N and that the speed of the car is constant.
          Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
      • Pnet = Wnet/t  average net power defined
        • Power
          POW1A37394What is the net power supplied to a 1.00e5 kg YP (ship)
          as it accelerates from rest to 5.00 m/s in 1.00 min?

          Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
          POW2A36884A coffee filter with a mass of 2.00 g falling at terminal velocity
          falls 1.00 m in 1.83 s. What is the net average power supplied
          to the coffee filter by all forces during this 1.83 s?
          Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
      • P = F*v*cos($q) or P = F_x*v_x + F_y*v_y  instantaneous power
        • Power
          POW3A47782What is the maximum constant velocity with which a
          2000 W motor could lift a 100 kg crate straight upward?

          Note: For this problem, neglect the cable and model the
          motor as the source of an APPLIED force on the crate.
          Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
          POW5B69579What power engine is required for a 1800 kg car to climb
          a 15 degrees grade at a steady 26.7 m/s (60 mph), if the drag
          force on the car is 800 N at this speed?
          [XXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
          Assume the car is moving to the right.
          POW5C49396.5A physics student determines that the total drag force on
          his car at 24.6 m/s (55 mph) is 550 N. The mass of
          the car is 1500 kg. What instantaneous power engine
          is required for this car to go up a 5 deg incline at
          a steady rate of 24.6 m/s?
          [XXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
          Assume the car is moving to the right.
          POW5D723.583What power engine is required for a 1500 kg car to climb
          a 10 deg grade at 26.7 m/s and still be able to accelerate
          at 2.2 m/s^2. Assume that the drag force on the car at
          this speed is 750 N.
          [XXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
          Assume the car is moving to the right.
          POW6A103263A physics student decides to measure the power required for
          his 1900 kg car to maintain a constant speed of 24.6 m/s
          (55 mph) on level ground. To get the necessary data, he
          puts the car into neutral (coasting) and finds that during
          a period of 7.5 s, the speed drops from 25.7 m/s (57.5 mph)
          to 23.5 m/s (52.5 mph). Use these data to calculate
          the drag force acting on the car under while slowing down
          on level ground.
          [XXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
          Now, use this result to find the power required from
          the car's engine to maintain the car at a constant speed
          of 24.6 m/s (55 mph).
          [XXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
          Assume the car is moving to the right.
      • P = 4*$p*r^2*I  relation of power and intensity (spherical emitter)
        • Waves
          WAVE1541884A sound source emitting sound equally in all directions
          results in a sound intensity of 100 dB at a distance of
          4.0 m from the source.
          What is the power output of the source in watts?
          [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
          Iref=1.0e-12 W/m^2 is the reference intensity.
          WAVE1740984.5If an omnidirectional (same intensity in all directions)
          sound source produces a sound intensity of 68 dB at 5.0 m,
          at what distance will the intensity be down by 6 dB to 62 dB?
          [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
          Iref=1.0e-12 W/m^2 is the reference intensity.
          WAVE1817496If the speaker at a rock concert puts out 100 W
          of acoustical power, at what distance from the speaker
          will the sound level be 120 dB, the threshold for pain?
          [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
          Assume that the source is omnidirectional.
          Iref=1.0e-12 W/m^2 is the reference intensity.
        • Electromagnetic Waves
          EMWAVE3A330.583.5What is the average intensity at a point P
          8.0 km to the right of a radio transmitter broadcasting
          isotropically at an average power of 280 kW?
          [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
      • P = I*A  relation of power and intensity (uniform over surface)
        • Electromagnetic Waves
          EMWAVE430684A company is designing a facility to convert solar radiation
          into electrical power. The system will require 2.0 MW of
          electrical power and will have a solar energy to electrical
          energy conversion efficiency of 28%. What must the effective
          area of the solar energy collectors be, if they are perfectly
          absorbing and one assumes a constant incident solar intensity
          of 960 W/m^2?
          [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
      • Inet = I1 + I2 + ...  net intensity defined
        • Waves
          WAVE16367.589Three sound sources individually produce intensities of
          60 dB, 65 dB and 80 dB. When these sources act together,
          their intensities add. What is the resulting sound
          intensity in dB, when the three sources are on at
          the same time?
          [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
          Iref=1.0e-12 W/m^2 is the reference intensity.
      • $b = 10*log10(I/Iref)  intensity & decibels
        • Waves
          WAVE1541884A sound source emitting sound equally in all directions
          results in a sound intensity of 100 dB at a distance of
          4.0 m from the source.
          What is the power output of the source in watts?
          [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
          Iref=1.0e-12 W/m^2 is the reference intensity.
          WAVE16367.589Three sound sources individually produce intensities of
          60 dB, 65 dB and 80 dB. When these sources act together,
          their intensities add. What is the resulting sound
          intensity in dB, when the three sources are on at
          the same time?
          [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
          Iref=1.0e-12 W/m^2 is the reference intensity.
          WAVE1740984.5If an omnidirectional (same intensity in all directions)
          sound source produces a sound intensity of 68 dB at 5.0 m,
          at what distance will the intensity be down by 6 dB to 62 dB?
          [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
          Iref=1.0e-12 W/m^2 is the reference intensity.
          WAVE1817496If the speaker at a rock concert puts out 100 W
          of acoustical power, at what distance from the speaker
          will the sound level be 120 dB, the threshold for pain?
          [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
          Assume that the source is omnidirectional.
          Iref=1.0e-12 W/m^2 is the reference intensity.
      • I = Iref*10^($b/10)  intensity & decibels
        • Waves

          • Linear Momentum
            LMOM1A45769An 84.0 kg ice skater moving at 9.50 m/s crashes into a
            stationary skater of mass 78.0 kg. If the two skaters slide
            across the ice together, how fast are they traveling?
            Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            Note: This problem seeks a property of a compound body.
            Use the body tool to introduce a label for the compound
            before asking for "light bulb" help.
            LMOM1B37894A 100.0 kg ice skater moving at 8.20 m/s crashes into a
            stationary skater of mass 67.0 kg. After the collision the
            two skaters slide across the ice together.
            How fast are they travelling after the collision?
            [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            LMOM2A50280A 3.20 kg bowling ball collides head-on with a 1.30 kg
            bowling pin which is initially at rest. After the collision, the
            bowling ball is still moving forward but now has a speed of
            1.82 m/s while the pin is sent flying forward at 2.90 m/s.
            What was the magnitude of the ball's velocity before the
            collision? Ignore any rotation of the ball.

            Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            LMOM2B109074A billiard ball is moving at 3.10 m/s when it hits a
            stationary ball of the same mass. After the collision, the
            second ball moves at 2.40 m/s at an angle of 60.0 deg to
            the original line of motion. Find the magnitude and
            direction of the velocity of the first ball after the collision.
            Magnitude: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            Direction: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            LMOM3A139768A billiard ball is moving in the positive x direction when it hits
            a stationary ball of the same mass. The collision is elastic and
            after the collision, the second ball moves at 2.30 m/s at an angle
            of 30.0 deg to the original line of motion. Find the magnitude
            and direction of the velocity of the first ball after the collision.
            magnitude: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            direction: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            To solve this problem, you may need to do any necessary algebra
            yourself.
            LMOM4A82886A space probe including a telescope has a combined mass of
            4000 kg, and is cruising through empty space at a speed of
            15.0 m/s. The telescope, which has a mass of 1500 kg, separates
            from the probe and travels at an angle of 20.0 deg to the
            forward direction, while the probe's path is now at 5.00 deg
            on the other side of the original trajectory.

            Find the magnitudes of the velocities of the telescope and the
            probe after they separate.
            probe: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            telescope: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            LMOM5127757A bullet of mass 30 g and velocity 300 m/s in the x-direction
            passes through a pendulum bob of mass 700 g. The bullet has
            a final velocity of 150 m/s in the x-direction after passing
            through the pendulum bob. The pendulum bob is supported by
            a rigid rod that has a length l and negligible mass. What is
            the maximum value of l such that the pendulum bob will swing
            in a complete vertical circle. (You may assume that
            the pendulum bob does not lose any mass.)
            length: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            LMOM6137967A space probe, mass 722 kg, is moving to the right at 15 km/s
            toward a planet, mass 1.02e26 kg. In the same reference frame
            the planet is moving at 7 km/s toward the probe. The probe
            makes an arc of 180 deg around the planet due to
            the gravitational force.
            After the probe moves away from the planet, how fast is it
            moving in the original reference frame?
            velocity (magnitude): [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            LMOM7103264A block of mass m1 is sliding along a frictionless track.
            The original velocity of m1 is 3 m/s in the positive
            x-direction. There is a strong magnet in m1 with its
            north seeking pole pointed in the direction of its
            motion. Block m1 interacts with block m2 which was initially
            at rest. Block m2 has a similar strong magnet embedded within
            it with the north seeking pole pointed at m1.
            In this problem, the blocks never touch and it may be
            considered as a perfectly elastic collision in one dimension.

            For m1 = 3 kg and m2 = 5 kg, determine
            the x-component of the final velocity of each block.
            final v_x of m1: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            final v_x of m2: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            IMP157877A 0.145 kg baseball pitched at 40 m/s is hit on
            a horizontal line back to the pitcher at 52 m/s.
            If the contact time of the ball with the bat is
            4.7e-3 s, calculate the magnitude of the average
            force acting on the ball due the bat.
            [XXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            Assume the batter is to the right of the pitcher.
            IMP252579A 15 gram bullet traveling at 230 m/s penetrates
            a 2.0 kg wood target and emerges going 140 m/s.
            If the target is initially at rest on a
            frictionless surface when hit, how fast does
            the target move after the bullet emerges?
            [XXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            The bullet is moving to the right.
            IMP3A49094A tennis ball with a mass of 0.065 kg and a speed
            of 33 m/s strikes a wall at an angle of 45 degrees
            and rebounds at 28 m/s at an angle of 45 degrees,
            as shown below. What is the impulse given to the ball?
            J_x = [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            J_y = [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]

          • Linear Momentum
            IMP157877A 0.145 kg baseball pitched at 40 m/s is hit on
            a horizontal line back to the pitcher at 52 m/s.
            If the contact time of the ball with the bat is

        • J_y = F(avg)_y*t  impulse and force
        • J1_x + J2_x + ... = pf_x - pi_x  Newton's second law
          • Linear Momentum

            [XXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            The bullet is moving to the right.
            IMP3A49094A tennis ball with a mass of 0.065 kg and a speed
            of 33 m/s strikes a wall at an angle of 45 degrees
            and rebounds at 28 m/s at an angle of 45 degrees,
            as shown below. What is the impulse given to the ball?
            J_x = [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            J_y = [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]

            moving at a 45 degree angle as shown.
            strikes a wall and rebounds. If the impulse given
            to the ball by the wall is (-3,-1) N s, then what is
            the final momentum of the ball?
            p_x = [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            p_y = [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]

            moving at a 45 degree angle as shown.
            strikes a wall and rebounds. If the impulse given
            to the ball by the wall is (-3,0) N s, then what is
            the final momentum of the ball?
            magnitude = [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            direction = [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
        • J1_y + J2_y + ... = pf_y - pi_y  Newton's second law
          • Linear Momentum
            LMOM6137967A space probe, mass 722 kg, is moving to the right at 15 km/s
            toward a planet, mass 1.02e26 kg. In the same reference frame
            the planet is moving at 7 km/s toward the probe. The probe
            makes an arc of 180 deg around the planet due to
            the gravitational force.
            After the probe moves away from the planet, how fast is it
            moving in the original reference frame?
            velocity (magnitude): [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]

        • J12 = J21  Newton's third law (magnitude)
          • Linear Momentum
            LMOM6137967A space probe, mass 722 kg, is moving to the right at 15 km/s
            toward a planet, mass 1.02e26 kg. In the same reference frame
            the planet is moving at 7 km/s toward the probe. The probe
            makes an arc of 180 deg around the planet due to
            the gravitational force.
            After the probe moves away from the planet, how fast is it
            moving in the original reference frame?
            velocity (magnitude): [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            IMP252579A 15 gram bullet traveling at 230 m/s penetrates
            a 2.0 kg wood target and emerges going 140 m/s.
            If the target is initially at rest on a
            frictionless surface when hit, how fast does
            the target move after the bullet emerges?
            [XXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            The bullet is moving to the right.
        • J12_x = -J21_x  Newton's third law (x component)
          • Linear Momentum
            LMOM6137967A space probe, mass 722 kg, is moving to the right at 15 km/s
            toward a planet, mass 1.02e26 kg. In the same reference frame
            the planet is moving at 7 km/s toward the probe. The probe
            makes an arc of 180 deg around the planet due to
            the gravitational force.
            After the probe moves away from the planet, how fast is it
            moving in the original reference frame?

        • J12_y = -J21_y  Newton's third law (y component)
        • Rcm_x = (m1*r1_x + m2*r2_x + ...)/(m1 + m2 + ...)  center of mass
          • Linear Momentum
            CM1640.557.5The distance between the carbon atom and the oxygen atom in
            a CO molecule is 1.13e-10 m. If the mass of the oxygen
            atom is 16 u and the mass of the carbon atom is 12 u,
            what is the location of the center of mass of
            the CO molecule?
            x-component: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            y-component: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            Place the coordinate origin at the center of the oxygen atom.
            Place the carbon atom on the positive x-axis.
            u = 1.6605e-27 kg is an atomic mass unit.
            CM2526.556.5The masses of the Earth and the Moon are 5.98e24 kg and
            7.35e22 kg respectively. If the separation between their
            centers is 3.84e8 m, what is the location of
            the center of mass of the Earth-Moon system?
            x-component: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            y-component: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            Place the coordinate origin at the center of the earth.
            Place the moon on the positive x-axis.
            CM351274An empty 1200 kg car has its center of mass 2.4 m behind the front
            of the car. If a driver sits down in the front seat, 2.7 m from
            the front of the car and three passengers sit in the back seat,
            4.0 m from the front of the car, what will be the location of
            the center of mass of the car-passenger system assuming that each
            passenger has a mass of 75 kg?
            x-component: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            Place the coordinate origin at the front of the car.
            Assume the front of the car is to the right.
        • Rcm_y = (m1*r1_y + m2*r2_y + ...)/(m1 + m2 + ...)  center of mass
          • Linear Momentum

            Place the moon on the positive x-axis.
      • Rotational
        • L_z = I*$w_z  angular momentum defined
          • Angular Momentum
            MOMR1A34986A meterstick of mass 0.500 kg is rotated at 6*$p rad/s
            counter-clockwise about the z-axis through its midpoint.
            What is the magnitude of its angular momentum?
            [XXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            What is the direction of its angular momentum?
            {[__+z] [__-z]}
            MOMR1B215.583A steel bar of length 0.750 m and mass 2.500 kg
            is rotated at a rate of 4*$p rad/s clockwise about
            the z-axis through its midpoint.
            What is the magnitude of its angular momentum?
            [XXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            What is the direction of its angular momentum?
            {[__+z] [__-z]}
            MOMR2A27992A hoop of mass 2.00 kg, with radius 0.680 m, is rotated at
            3*$p rad/s clockwise about the z-axis through its midpoint.
            What is the magnitude of its angular momentum?
            [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            What is the direction of its angular momentum?
            {[__+z] [__-z]}
            MOMR2B22693A hoop of mass 1.75 kg, with radius 0.720 m, is rotated at
            2.5*$p rad/s counter-clockwise about the z-axis through its
            midpoint. What is the magnitude of its angular momentum?
            [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            MOMR3A36076A man stands on a frictionless platform that is rotating
            counterclockwise about the vertical z axis at an angular
            velocity of 2.4 * $p rad/s. His arms are outstretched
            and he holds a weight in each hand.

            With his arms in this position, the rotational inertia of
            the entire man-weights-platform system is 7.50 kg*m^2.

            If the man moves his arms and the weights so that the
            rotational inertia of the system decreases to 2.25 kg*m^2,
            what is the magnitude of his new angular velocity?
            Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            Note: use the top view to draw your diagrams
            MOMR4A551.575Two disks are mounted on low friction bearings on the same
            axle and can be brought together so that they couple and
            rotate as one unit. The first disk has a moment of inertia of
            2.81 kg*m^2 and is rotating at 8.43 rad/s counterclockwise
            about the z-axis. The second disk, with a moment of inertia
            of 7.80 kg*m^2, is spinning at 15.0 rad/s in the same direction
            as the first disk.
            If the two disks are then coupled together, what would be
            the magnitude of their angular velocity after coupling?
            Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            Note: you should use the body tool to define a compound body
            consisting of disk1 and disk2.
        • L1i_z + L2i_z + ... = L1f_z + L2f_z + ...  conservation of angular momentum
          • Angular Momentum
            MOMR3A36076A man stands on a frictionless platform that is rotating
            counterclockwise about the vertical z axis at an angular
            velocity of 2.4 * $p rad/s. His arms are outstretched
            and he holds a weight in each hand.

            With his arms in this position, the rotational inertia of
            the entire man-weights-platform system is 7.50 kg*m^2.
