            2.81 kg*m^2 and is rotating at 8.43 rad/s counterclockwise

    • Fluids
      • P2 - P1 = $r*g*(h1-h2)  pressure in fluid
      • 0.5*$r*v1^2 + $r*g*h1 + P1 = 0.5*$r*v2^2 + $r*g*h2 + P2  Bernoulli equation
        • Fluids
          FLUIDS2418.593What is the pressure at point1 in a horizontal pipe where the velocity of
          the water at point1 is 5 m/s and the velocity at point2 is 3 m/s?
          The mass density of water is 1.0e3 kg/m^3. Point2 is open to the air.
          Take both points to be at the zero level height.
          Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
          FLUIDS324399What is the pressure at point1 at a height of 0.0 m, in a pipe where the velocity of
          the water at point1 is 3 m/s and the velocity at point2 is 5 m/s? Take the height at
          point2 as 0.35 m, and the pressure at point2 as 2.6e5 Pa
          The mass density of water is 1.0e3 kg/m^3
          Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
          FLUIDS550188A water tower has a cross-section of 100 m^2, and is open at the top.
          There is a hole in the side of the tank at a position that is 10 m below
          the waterlevel in the tank at this instant. The area of the hole is 10 cm^2.
          Find the magnitude of the velocity of the water exiting the hole.

          Remember that wherever the water is open to the air, the pressure
          must be one atmosphere. The mass density of water is 1.0e3 kg/m^3.
          Take the zero-level of height to be at the surface of the water.
          Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
          FLUIDS6416.595.5A water tower has a cross-section of 100 m^2, and is open at the top.
          There is a hole of area 10 cm^2 in the side of the tank.
          Find the magnitude of the velocity of the fluid at point1 on the surface of
          the water (which will be the speed at which the water level is descending)
          at an instant when the waterlevel is 10 m above the hole.

          Remember that wherever the water is open to the air, the pressure must be
          one atmosphere. The mass density of water is 1.0e3 kg/m^3.
          Take the zero level of height to be at the level of the hole.
          Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]

      • Fp = P*A  pressure defined
        • Fluids
          FLUIDS8907.549.5A 90 kg man standing on a 10 kg piston of radius 1.2 m is in equilibrium
          due to the pressure in the hydraulic fluid below the piston.
          What is the pressure in the fluid at the location of the piston?
          Do NOT neglect the effect of the atmospheric pressure.
          Hint: You may consider the compound body of man and piston.
          Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
          FLUIDS961878An man standing on a smaller piston1 supported by a fluid can
          balance a much heavier object resting on a larger piston2 as shown.
          The mass of the man together with piston1 is 80 kg; the mass of the
          object together with piston2 is 1100 kg. The pistons are circular and
          the radius of the larger piston is 2 m. Determine the radius of the
          the smaller piston1. Neglect the effect of the atmospheric pressure
          which acts equally on both pistons.
          Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]

          EMWAVE535175A design team considering the use of a solar sail to propel
          a spacecraft using radiation from the sun. The average
          intensity (magnitude of the Poynting vector) at a point near
          the Earth is 1.3 kW/m^2. If the sail is a perfect reflector,
          what is the radiation pressure exerted on the sail due to
          the Sun's radiation?

          if the sail is a perfect reflector?
          area: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
      • $r = m/V  mass density defined
        • Fluids
          FLUIDS11438.584A block of copper is suspended in fresh water using a string.
          The volume of the block is 1.15e-6 m^3. The density of copper
          is 8900 kg/m^3. What is the tension in the string?
          (The density of fresh water is 1000 kg/m^3.)
          Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
          FLUIDS1229094A steel block that has a volume of 1.15e-5 m^3 sits on the bottom
          of a swimming pool. The density of steel is 7800 kg/m^3. The density
          of fresh water is 1000 kg/m^3. What is the normal force exerted by
          the pool on the block?
          Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
          FLUIDS1363785A scuba diver in full gear weighs 850 N. In order to make himself
          neutrally buoyant in fresh water he must add 8 kg of lead weights.
          The density of fresh water is 1000 kg/m^3 . Ignoring the volume
          of the lead weights, what is the average density of the scuba
          diver and his gear?
          Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
          Take 'diver' to mean the diver together with his gear.
          Assume the weights rest on the diver's back.
          Hint: consider the compound body of diver and weights.
          FLUIDS14616.575A helium balloon has a volume of 1.57 m^3 when it is fully inflated.
          What is the maximum mass that can be supported by this balloon in air?
          The density of helium is 0.179 kg/m^3. The density of air is 1.29 kg/m^3.

          Take the mass of the balloon surface to be included as part of the
          supported mass, and treat the weight of the balloon itself as entirely
          due to the weight of the helium filling its volume. You may consider
          the balloon and mass as a compound body.
          Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
          FLUIDS1549369Ice has a density of 917 kg/m^3. The density of seawater is 1025 kg/m^3.
          To determine the percentage of the volume that is submerged whenever ice
          floats on seawater, consider a floating chunk of ice with a total volume
          of 100 m^3 and find the volume of the submerged portion of this chunk.

          Hint: Represent the chunk as a compound body composed of ice_submerged
          and ice_above_water.
          Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]

    • Electricity and Magnetism
      • Q = N*q  charged particles
        • Electric Field
          CHARGE1B19886A student rubs a plastic rod with a cloth. This results in
          the rod having a net charge of -14 nC.
          a. Have electrons been added to the rod or have protons
          been removed?
          { [__electrons added] [__protons removed]}
          b. This is because:
          { [__protons and the rod both have positive charges]
          [__electrons can be moved more easily than protons]
          [__electrons and protons attract because they have opposite charges]}
          c. How many charged particles have been transferred to/from
          the rod?
          Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXX]
          Use the appropriate elementary charge, plus or minus
          1.60e-19 C, as the charge of the particle.
      • F = kelec*abs(q1*q2)/r^2  Coulomb's law (magnitude)
        • Electric Field

          the masses are 1 m apart.
          Find the magnitude of the Coulomb force exerted on Q2.
          Force: [XXXXXXXXXXXX]

      • F = abs(q)*E  electric field (magnitude)
        • Electric Field
          FOR4A28492A charged particle is in a region where there is an
          electric field E of magnitude 17.8 kV/m at an angle of
          37 degrees above the positive x-axis. If the charge
          on the particle is 3.4e-6 C, find the magnitude of the
          force on the particle due to the electric field E.
          Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]

          FOR11A1063.548.5A fully ionized alpha particle with a charge of 3.20e-19 C
          and a mass of 6.64e-27 kg is initially moving in
          the x direction with a velocity of 1.50e+3 m/s. The particle
          enters a region where there is a uniform electric field in

          What will be the velocity of the particle after it has
          moved 0.500 m in the x direction?
          x-component: [XXXXXXXXXXXX]
          y-component: [XXXXXXXXXXXX]
          In this problem, gravity can be ignored.

          ELEC3B90159An electron (qe = -1.60e-19 C; me = 9.11e-31 kg) is in a region,
          between two parallel charged plates, that produce a uniform electric
          field E of magnitude 2.0e+4 N/C. The separation between the plates
          is 1.5 cm. The electron undergoes a constant acceleration from rest
          near the negative plate and passes through a tiny hole in the positive
          plate (see Figure below). Find the velocity of the electron as it leaves
          the hole.
          Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXX]
          In this problem, gravity can be ignored.
          ELEC4B485.589A proton (qp = 1.60e-19 C; mp = 1.67e-27 kg) is in a region where
          there is a uniform electric field E of magnitude 320 N/C, directed
          along the positive x-axis. The proton accelerates from rest and
          reaches a speed of 1.20e+5 m/s. How long does it take the proton to
          reach this speed?
          Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXX]
          In this problem, gravity can be ignored.

          of magnitude 4.0e-12 N/C, directed along the negative y-axis.

          velocity of 4.3 m/s. How far will the electron travel before it
          momentarily comes to rest?

          In this problem, please include gravity.

        • Electric Field

          magnitude of the electric field caused by the particle
          at point1 = (-4 cm, 7 cm).
          Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
          GAUSS1197856An arrangement of two opposite charges is called
          an electric dipole. Consider an electric dipole made of
          two elementary charges, Qpos=1.6e-19 C and Qneq=-1.6e-19 C,
          separated by a distance of 1e-6 m, as shown below.
          Let S1 be a spherical Gaussian surface, radius 4e-6 m,
          containing the dipole at the center.
          What is the total electric flux flowing through S1?
          flux: [XXXXXXXXXXXX]
          What is the magnitude of the net electric field at a point P1
          located 4e-6 m above the center of the dipole?
          magnitude of net E: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
          In fact, the electric field is nonzero over the entire
          surface S1.
        • Electric Potential

          electric field at point p1 (0 cm, 0 cm) due to these charges.
          Potential at p1: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
          x component of E: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
          y component of E: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]

        • Electric Field
          FOR9A88476A 1.0e-7 C charge, charge1, is located at (4 cm, 0 cm) and
          a 2.0e-7 C charge, charge2, is located at (-3 cm, 0 cm), as shown.
          Find the net electric field at the point p1 = (0 cm, 2 cm).
          x-component: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
          y-component: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]

          GAUSS1197856An arrangement of two opposite charges is called
          an electric dipole. Consider an electric dipole made of
          two elementary charges, Qpos=1.6e-19 C and Qneq=-1.6e-19 C,
          separated by a distance of 1e-6 m, as shown below.
          Let S1 be a spherical Gaussian surface, radius 4e-6 m,
          containing the dipole at the center.
          What is the total electric flux flowing through S1?
          flux: [XXXXXXXXXXXX]
          What is the magnitude of the net electric field at a point P1
          located 4e-6 m above the center of the dipole?
          magnitude of net E: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
          In fact, the electric field is nonzero over the entire
          surface S1.
        • Electric Potential

      • $Fe = A*E*cos($qE - $qn) or $Fe = A*(E_x*n_x + E_y*n_y)  electric flux (uniform field)
        • Electric Field
          GAUSS357853A cube with sides of 0.5 m rests in the x-z plane as shown
          below. If there is a uniform electric field in the region
          with components E_x=200 N/C and E_y = 300 N/C, find
          the electric flux through the right side of the cube, S.
          flux: [XXXXXXXXXXXX]
          The unit normal should be pointing out of the cube.
          Use Alt-Shift-f to type $F.
          GAUSS655296A surface S, a circle of radius 0.4 m, rests in the yz-plane,
          as shown below. The region contains a uniform electric field
          pointing in a direction 30 degrees above the x-axis.
          If the electric flux through S is 8 N.m^2/C, what is
          the magnitude of the electric field?
          magnitude of E: [XXXXXXXXXXXX]
          The unit normal should be pointing to the right of S.
          Use Alt-Shift-f to type $F.
          GAUSS861753.5A disk D of radius 10 cm is rotated counter-clockwise
          as shown. The disk lies in a region containing a uniform
          electric field, magnitude 500 N/C, pointing upwards.
          Find the electric flux through D at each time.
          flux at T0: [XXXXXXXXXXXX]
          flux at T1: [XXXXXXXXXXXX]
          flux at T2: [XXXXXXXXXXXX]
          Use Alt-Shift-f to type $F.
          GAUSS985680An empty cube (0.3 m on each edge) is placed in a uniform
          electric field of 1200 N/C pointing to the right.
          What is the electric flux through the each side of the cube?
          left: [XXXXXXXXX] right: [XXXXXXXXX]
          top: [XXXXXXXXX] bottom: [XXXXXXXXX]
          front: [XXXXXXXXX] back: [XXXXXXXXX]
          What is the electric flux through the entire cube?
          flux: [XXXXXXXXX]
          Use Alt-Shift-f to type $F.
          GAUSS1060278An electrically neutral copper disk (area 100 cm^2)
          is placed in a region of uniform electric field of 200 N/C.
          The electric field is directed perpendicular to the disk.

          In this problem, we will use Gauss' law to calculate
          the charge on the left surface of the disk.
          Which Gaussian surface, shown below, should we use?
          { [__S1] [__S2] [__either S1 or S2]}
          Find the charge on the left surface of the disk.
          charge on left surface: [XXXXXXXXX]
          You can neglect the sides of the gaussian surfaces, S1 and S2,
          since they are parallel to the electric field.
          Assume the disk is fairly thin and neglect any edge effects.
          Use Alt-Shift-f to type $F.
      • d$Fe/dt = E.n*dA/dt  derivative of electric flux, uniform field
      • $F = $F1 + $F2 + ...  adding fluxes

        • Electric Field
          DIP1A947.560A small rigid object carries equal magnitude positive and
          negative charges of 2.3 nC separated by 1.8 mm. The system
          is oriented as shown in the figure below with the vector that
          runs from the negative to the positive charge oriented at an
          angle of 30 deg with respect to a uniform external electric
          field of 4500 N/C in the positive x direction.
          a. What is the magnitude of the electric dipole moment for
          these charges?

          b. What is the magnitude of the torque on the dipole due to
          the external field?
          torque: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
          c. What is the potential energy of the dipole in the position
          given?
          potential energy: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]

          work would be required to rotate this dipole from alignment
          with the external field to an angle of 43 degrees with
          respect to the field?
          work: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]

          forces.

        • Electric Field

      • U = -p*E*cos($qp - $qE) or U = -(p_x*E_x + p_y*E_y)  potential energy of electric dipole
        • Electric Field
          DIP1A947.560A small rigid object carries equal magnitude positive and
          negative charges of 2.3 nC separated by 1.8 mm. The system
          is oriented as shown in the figure below with the vector that
          runs from the negative to the positive charge oriented at an
          angle of 30 deg with respect to a uniform external electric
          field of 4500 N/C in the positive x direction.
          a. What is the magnitude of the electric dipole moment for
          these charges?
          dipole moment: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]

          the external field?

          given?

      • B_y = $m0*q*(v_z*n_x - v_x*n_z)/(4*$p*r^2)  Biot-Savart law for a point charge (y component)
      • B_z = $m0*q*v*sin($qn-$qv)/(4*$p*r^2) or B_z = $m0*q*(v_x*n_y - v_y*n_x)/(4*$p*r^2)  Biot-Savart law for a point charge (z component)

        • Electromagnetic Induction
          FARA11A66749A circular coil of 100 turns bounding surface S, area 0.36 m^2,
          is initially lying flat in the x-z plane. During a period of
          0.25 seconds, the coil is rotated 90 degrees about the z-axis
          so that it lies in the y-z plane, as shown below.
          If there is a uniform magnetic field of 0.67 T
          in the y direction, what is the average emf generated in
          the coil during the rotation?
          Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXX]
          Use voltage across coil to represent the emf.
          Use Alt-Shift-f to type $F.

      • d$Fb/dt = B.n*dA/dt  rate of change in magnetic flux (constant field)
        • Electromagnetic Induction
          FARA972148Consider the system below where a conducting bar is pushed at
          10 m/s to the right along conducting rails that are separated
          by 2.5 m. If the resistor has a value of 20 ohm and there is
          a uniform magnetic field out of the screen with a magnitude of
          1.2 T, what will be the current flowing through the resistor?
          (Hint: How is the flux through the region S changing?)
          Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXX]
          Use Alt-Shift-f to type $F. Use the rate of change in length
          of the rectangular area S to represent the speed of the bar.
          Choose the normal to surface S to be out of the screen.
          Is the current through the resistor flowing
          {[__up] or [__down]}?

      • E = B*c  ratio of fields in electromagnetic wave

      • V1 + V2 + V3 ... = 0  Kirchoff's loop rule
        • Capacitance

          EPOW338282A real battery, like a car battery can be modeled as a pure emf
          (electromotive force) in series with an internal resistance, Ri.
          In the circuit below the emf of the battery, Vb, is 12 V. The
          voltage V2-V1 is called the terminal voltage of the battery and is
          given by V2-V1 = Vb - I*Ri. If a very low resistance, R1= 0.05 ohm,
          is put across the terminals of the battery and Ri=0.1 ohm, what is
          the power loss in R1 and in Ri? Since all of the heat generated in
          Ri is inside the battery, this could be a safety hazard!
          in R1: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
          in Ri: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]

            R5=70.0 ohm, R6 = 80.0 ohm, R7 = 90.0 ohm, and R8 = 100 ohm.
            Do not combine the series resistors.
            Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]

            EPOW338282A real battery, like a car battery can be modeled as a pure emf
            (electromotive force) in series with an internal resistance, Ri.
            In the circuit below the emf of the battery, Vb, is 12 V. The
            voltage V2-V1 is called the terminal voltage of the battery and is
            given by V2-V1 = Vb - I*Ri. If a very low resistance, R1= 0.05 ohm,
            is put across the terminals of the battery and Ri=0.1 ohm, what is
            the power loss in R1 and in Ri? Since all of the heat generated in
            Ri is inside the battery, this could be a safety hazard!
            in R1: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            in Ri: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]

            FARA972148Consider the system below where a conducting bar is pushed at
            10 m/s to the right along conducting rails that are separated
            by 2.5 m. If the resistor has a value of 20 ohm and there is
            a uniform magnetic field out of the screen with a magnitude of
            1.2 T, what will be the current flowing through the resistor?
            (Hint: How is the flux through the region S changing?)
            Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXX]
            Use Alt-Shift-f to type $F. Use the rate of change in length
            of the rectangular area S to represent the speed of the bar.
            Choose the normal to surface S to be out of the screen.
            Is the current through the resistor flowing
            {[__up] or [__down]}?

            of the capacitors C1, C2, C3, C4, C5, C6. The values of the

            C4=52.0 $mF, C5=70.0 $mF, C6=38.0 $mF and the battery voltage
            is 10.0 V. Do not combine the series capacitors.
            Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]

        • V = -L*dIdt  inductor EMF
          • Inductance
            IND1A18894The current through an inductor L1 that has an inductance of 3.2 H
            is increased uniformly in time from 2.0 A in a direction from left
            to right to 3.5 A in a time of 3 s. Determine the emf (voltage)
            across the ends of the inductor (Vb-Va) throughout this time period.
            Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            IND1B10498The current through an inductor L1 is uniformly changed from 3.2 A
            to the right to 3.5 A to the left in 2.7 s. During that time it
            develops a constant emf (voltage) between its ends (Vb-Va) of 11.3 V.
            What is its inductance?
            Take current to the right to be positive.
            Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            IND1C11099The current through an inductor L1 with a self-inductance of 15 H
            is uniformly changed over a period of 3.0 s. During that
            period it develops a constant emf (voltage) between its ends (Vb-Va)
            of 12 V. If the initial current was 4 A to the right, what is the
            current through the inductor at the end of that 3 s period?
            Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]

            the circuit to oscillate with decreasing amplitude. At a given instant of time,
            T1, the current in the circuit is 180 mA and is flowing in the direction indicated and the
            current is increasing at a rate of 32 A/s. At T1, find: the charge on C1, the
            energy stored on C1 and L1, and the power dissipated through R1. (Note: a
            negative result for charge on C1 is possible; this means the actual positive
            and negative sides are reversed from those assumed in the diagram.)

          LENS5A50273Consider an uncorrected eye which forms a image of an object placed
          2.0 m in front of it 2.5 mm in front of the retina. What focal length
          lens needs to be place in front of the eye to put the corrected image
          of this object on the retina, which is 5.0 cm from the front of the eye?
          Assume that the thin lens combination (touching lenses) equation applies.
          Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
          Assume the following definitions:
          "eye" = the uncorrected natural lens of the eye
          "lens" = the corrective lens by itself
          LENS5B28091Consider an uncorrected eye which tries to form an image of an object
          placed 2.0 m in front of it 2.5 mm behind the retina. What focal length
          lens needs to be placed in front of the eye to put the corrected image,
          of this object on the retina, which is 5.0 cm from the front of the eye?

          Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
          Assume the following definitions:
          "eye" = the uncorrected natural lens of the eye
          "lens" = the corrective lens by itself

      • 1/f12 = 1/f1 + 1/f2  compound lens (touching lenses)
        • Optics
          LENS5A50273Consider an uncorrected eye which forms a image of an object placed
          2.0 m in front of it 2.5 mm in front of the retina. What focal length
          lens needs to be place in front of the eye to put the corrected image
          of this object on the retina, which is 5.0 cm from the front of the eye?
          Assume that the thin lens combination (touching lenses) equation applies.
          Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
          Assume the following definitions:
          "eye" = the uncorrected natural lens of the eye
          "lens" = the corrective lens by itself
          LENS5B28091Consider an uncorrected eye which tries to form an image of an object
          placed 2.0 m in front of it 2.5 mm behind the retina. What focal length
          lens needs to be placed in front of the eye to put the corrected image,
          of this object on the retina, which is 5.0 cm from the front of the eye?
          Assume that the thin lens combination (touching lenses) equation applies.
          Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
          Assume the following definitions:
          "eye" = the uncorrected natural lens of the eye
          "lens" = the corrective lens by itself
      • n = c/v  index of refraction
        • Optics
          REF138984A light beam that has a frequency of 6.0e14 Hz is moving
          through a medium that has an index of refraction (for this

          wavelength of the light in a vacuum

          the wavelength of the light in the medium, and
          wavelength = [XXXXXXXXXX]
          the speed of this light in the medium?

          REF2A39975A light ray initially in air enters a transparent material
          at an angle of incidence of 35 deg, and the transmitted ray
          is refracted at an angle of 23 deg. What is the index of
          refraction of the material and what is the speed of light in
          the material?
          index of refraction = [XXXXXXXXXX]
          wave speed = [XXXXXXXXXX]
          The index of refraction of air is approximately the same
          as the index of refraction of a vacuum: n = 1.00.
          REF2B24889A light ray initially in water enters a transparent material
          at an angle of incidence of 28 deg, and the transmitted ray is
          refracted at an angle of 31 deg. If the index of refraction
          of water is 1.33, what is the index of refraction of the second
          medium and what is the speed of light in the second medium?

          wave speed = [XXXXXXXXXX]
      • n=1  index of refraction of vacuum
      • n1*sin($q1) = n2*sin($q2)  Snell's law

          REF2C38081.5When a underwater scuba diver sees the Sun at an apparent
          angle of 43 deg above the horizon, what is the actual
          elevation angle of the Sun above the horizon? Assume that
          the index of refraction of the water is 1.33.
          angle above water = [XXXXXXXXXX]
          Assume an index of refraction of 1.00 for the air.
          Use the direction of the appropriate line to represent
          the elevation angle.
          REF3A52960Determine the maximum angle for which the light rays incident
          upon the end of a light pipe (shown in the figure below) are
          subject to total internal reflection. Assume that the pipe has
          an index of refraction of 1.35 and the outside medium is air.
          Maxumum angle of incidence [XXXXXXXXXX]
          Assume an index of refraction of 1.00 for the air.
          REF4A34784When a beam of light is incident upon an interface between two
          materials, part of the beam is reflected and part is
          transmitted. When the direction of the reflected beam is
          perpendicular to the refracted beam, the reflected beam is
          polarized in a direction parallel to the surface between
          the two media. This incident angle that results in
          the condition is called the Brewster's angle or polarizing
          angle.

          What is Brewster's angle for light incident upon a piece of
          glass with n = 1.28 from air?
          angle [XXXXXXXXXX]
          Assume an index of refraction of 1.00 for the air.
          REF4B178.595Calculate the Brewster's or polarizing angle for light
          incident from a plastic material into a glass, where
          the index of refraction for the plastic is 1.18 and
          the index of refraction for the glass is 1.32.
          angle [XXXXXXXXXX]
          REF628971The maximum angle of for which the light rays incident upon
          the end of a light pipe, in the figure below, are subject
          to total internal reflection is 65 degrees. Assuming that
          the outside medium is air, find the index of refraction
          of the material that the pipe is made from.
          Index of refraction: [XXXXXXXXXXXXX]
          Assume an index of refraction of 1.00 for the air.

          polarized in a direction parallel to the surface between
          the two media. This incident angle that results in
          the condition is called the Brewster's angle or polarizing
          angle.

          emits a ultra sound signal of 40,000 Hz.

          in a northerly direction at 15 m/s and is is located north
          of the first bat.
          What frequency will the second bat receive?
          [XXXXXXXXXX]

          Assume north is in the vertical direction on the screen.
          WAVE1233266A submarine that is at rest picks up a sonar
          signal from a ship at a frequency of 521.9 Hz.
          If it is known that the signal is result of machinery
          that normally puts out a sound with a frequency of 520.0 Hz,
          what is the radial speed of the ship relative to the water?
          [XXXXXXXXXX]
          Is the ship mowing away from or toward the submarine?
          {[__away] [__towards]}
          Assume the speed of sound in sea water is 1560 m/s.
          Assume the ship is to the right of the sub.

          string will resonate.
          first [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
          second [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
          third [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
      • fbeat = abs(f1-f2)/2  beat frequency
        • Waves
          WAVE1326198A sound source emits sound of wavelengths 2.50 m
          and 2.64 m in air. How many beats per second will
          be heard?
          [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
          Assume the speed of sound in air is 340 m/s.
          WAVE14462.575.5Two speakers face each other at the ends of a long hall.
          The speakers are connected to the same source which produces
          a signal of 329 Hz. If a person walks toward one of
          the speakers at a constant speed of 1.7 m/s, what beat
          frequency will the person hear?
          [XXXXXXXXXX]
          Assume v(air) = 340 m/s.
          Assume the speakers and the person lie on the x-axis.
      • E = Ei*exp(-2*t/$t)  energy decay
        • Inductance
          LRC2A62969In the RLC circuit shown below (circuit1) R = 1.5 ohm,
          C = 2.0e-6 F and L = 12 mH. If the capacitor is charged and
          then the switch is closed, at what frequency will the circuit
          oscillate?
          Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
          How long will be required for the total energy stored in
          the circuit be reduced to 50% of its original value?
          Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
      • vw = c  speed of light
        • Electromagnetic Waves
          WAVE1934974A laser pulse is bounced off of a reflector on the Moon and
          returns to the Earth's surface. If the distance from the
          surface of the Moon to the surface of the Earth during this
          time is 3.84e8 m, what time is required for the round trip?
          [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
        • Optics
          REF138984A light beam that has a frequency of 6.0e14 Hz is moving
          through a medium that has an index of refraction (for this
          frequency) of 1.21. What are the
          wavelength of the light in a vacuum
          wavelength = [XXXXXXXXXX]
          the wavelength of the light in the medium, and
          wavelength = [XXXXXXXXXX]
          the speed of this light in the medium?
          wave speed = [XXXXXXXXXX]
          REF2A39975A light ray initially in air enters a transparent material
          at an angle of incidence of 35 deg, and the transmitted ray
          is refracted at an angle of 23 deg. What is the index of
          refraction of the material and what is the speed of light in
          the material?
          index of refraction = [XXXXXXXXXX]
          wave speed = [XXXXXXXXXX]
          The index of refraction of air is approximately the same
          as the index of refraction of a vacuum: n = 1.00.
          REF2B24889A light ray initially in water enters a transparent material
          at an angle of incidence of 28 deg, and the transmitted ray is
          refracted at an angle of 31 deg. If the index of refraction
          of water is 1.33, what is the index of refraction of the second
          medium and what is the speed of light in the second medium?
          index of refraction = [XXXXXXXXXX]
          wave speed = [XXXXXXXXXX]
  • Apply a Definition or Auxiliary Law
    • Kinematics
      • Translational
        • dnet_x = d1_x + d2_x + ...  net displacement

            over the whole run.

            of 37 deg west of north. Find the x and y components of the total

            before he finally catches it. Find the x and y components of the
            total displacement of the frisbee.

            components of the dog's total displacement?
            x component: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            y component: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]

            y component: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]

            Richmond leg of the journey.

            the brakes and slows down at a constant rate before coming

            terms of v0, d, and t01.

          • Work and Energy
            WE4A53183A 80 kg box, that is initially sliding with a speed of 4 m/s,
            slides 6 m along a horizontal surface before reaching the top
            of a frictionless incline. While sliding on the horizontal
            surface the box experiences a constant frictional force of
            58.2 N. What will be the speed of the box when it reaches
            the flat frictionless surface at the bottom of the incline
            which is 0.4 m high?
            [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            Choose the zero of gravitational potential energy to
            be at the bottom of the incline.
            WE5317.577.5A 20 kg box, that is initially sliding with a speed of 6 m/s,
            slides 5 m along a horizontal surface and then up
            a frictionless incline that is 0.5 m high. If the box
            experiences a constant frictional force of 39.2 N while
            on the bottom horizontal surface, what will be its speed when
            it reaches the top of the incline?
            [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            Choose the zero of gravitational potential energy to be
            at the bottom of the incline.

            VEC6A937.589At t = 0.00 s, a particle moving in the xy plane has a velocity
            of (3.00 i - 2.00 j) m/s at the origin. At t = 3.00 s, the particle's
            velocity is (9.00 i + 7.00 j) m/s.

            Find the average acceleration of the particle expressed in
            component form.
            Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX] i + [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX] j
            VEC6B39597At time t0, a particle moving in the xy plane has a velocity
            of (3.00 i + 4.00 j) m/s at the origin. At time t1 the particle's
            velocity is (- 1.00 i + 2.00 j) m/s. Its average acceleration
            over the time interval is (- 8.00 i - 4.00 j) m/s^2.

            Find the length of the time interval.
            Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            VEC6C44998At t = 0 s, a particle moving in the xy plane has a velocity
            of (4.00 i + 2.00 j) m/s at the origin. Its average acceleration
            over the next 3.00 s is (6.00 i + 7.00 j) m/s^2.

            Find the velocity of the particle at t=3.00 s expressed
            in component form.
            Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX] i + [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX] j
            VEC6D43998At t = 5.00 s, a particle moving in the xy plane has a velocity
            of (15.0 i + 18.0 j) m/s at the origin. Its average acceleration
            over the previous 5.00 s was (3.00 i + 2.00 j) m/s^2.

            Find the velocity of the particle at t = 0 s expressed in
            component form.
            Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX] i + [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX] j

            acceleration of the particle at t=5 s. (You may answer this
            question without drawing any vectors.)

          • Translational Kinematics
            KT6A30795A motorcyclist races along a flat road with an initial velocity
            of 1.00 m/s. At the finish line, 62.0 s later, he reaches a
            velocity of 15.0 m/s.

            Find the magnitude of the average acceleration.
            Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]

            KT7A132775A modern supertanker is gigantic: 1200 to 1300 ft long with
            a 200 ft beam. Fully loaded, it chugs along at about 16.0 knots
            (8.33 m/s). It can take 1200 s to bring it to a full stop.

            Calculate the magnitude of the corresponding acceleration
            in m/s and determine the magnitude of the displacement
            of the tanker as it slows to a stop.

            Displacement: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            KT7B6329A car is traveling at a constant velocity v0 when the driver
            notices a garbage can on the road in front of him. At that
            moment, the distance between the garbage can and the front
            of the car is d. After time T01 passes, the driver applies
            the brakes and slows down at a constant rate before coming
            to a halt just before the garbage can. Find the magnitude
            of the car's acceleration after the brakes are applied, in
            terms of v0, d, and t01.
            Acceleration: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            You will need to do the algebra by hand.

            at a constant 2.00 m/s^2 for 3.00 s, then very rapidly roars up
            to 4.00 m/s^2 and holds the acceleration constant.
            What is its approximate average acceleration over the
            first 5.00 s of its motion?
            Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]

            When the box reaches p1, it is sliding at a speed of 3.7 m/s.

          • Power
            POW6A103263A physics student decides to measure the power required for
            his 1900 kg car to maintain a constant speed of 24.6 m/s
            (55 mph) on level ground. To get the necessary data, he
            puts the car into neutral (coasting) and finds that during
            a period of 7.5 s, the speed drops from 25.7 m/s (57.5 mph)
            to 23.5 m/s (52.5 mph). Use these data to calculate
            the drag force acting on the car under while slowing down
            on level ground.
            [XXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            Now, use this result to find the power required from
            the car's engine to maintain the car at a constant speed
            of 24.6 m/s (55 mph).
            [XXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            Assume the car is moving to the right.

            In this problem, gravity can be ignored.
        • a(avg)_y = (vf_y - vi_y)/t 
          • Vectors
            VEC6A937.589At t = 0.00 s, a particle moving in the xy plane has a velocity
            of (3.00 i - 2.00 j) m/s at the origin. At t = 3.00 s, the particle's
            velocity is (9.00 i + 7.00 j) m/s.

            Find the average acceleration of the particle expressed in
            component form.
            Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX] i + [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX] j
            VEC6B39597At time t0, a particle moving in the xy plane has a velocity
            of (3.00 i + 4.00 j) m/s at the origin. At time t1 the particle's
            velocity is (- 1.00 i + 2.00 j) m/s. Its average acceleration
            over the time interval is (- 8.00 i - 4.00 j) m/s^2.

            Find the length of the time interval.
            Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            VEC6C44998At t = 0 s, a particle moving in the xy plane has a velocity
            of (4.00 i + 2.00 j) m/s at the origin. Its average acceleration
            over the next 3.00 s is (6.00 i + 7.00 j) m/s^2.

            Find the velocity of the particle at t=3.00 s expressed
            in component form.
            Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX] i + [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX] j
            VEC6D43998At t = 5.00 s, a particle moving in the xy plane has a velocity

            over the previous 5.00 s was (3.00 i + 2.00 j) m/s^2.

            Find the velocity of the particle at t = 0 s expressed in
            component form.
            Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX] i + [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX] j

            castle. The slope makes an angle of 12.0 deg with respect to the

            horizontal and hits the base of the castle wall, what will be the

            the wall? HINT: Use a horizontal x axis.

            KT12C100059A cannon is on the slope of a hill 132.6 m down the slope from
            a castle. The slope makes an angle of 12.0 deg with respect
            to the horizontal. If the cannon is pointed 45.0 deg above
            the horizontal and has a muzzle velcity of 40.2 m/s, what will
            be the x and y components of the velocity of the cannonball as
            it hits the wall.
            x-component: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            y-component: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            Note that the x-component of the displacement of the cannonball
            during T0 to T1 is equal to the x-component of the relative
            position of the castle with respect to the cannon.

            to his hands a second later?

            At low speeds air friction is negligible.

            Note that the x-component of the displacement of the cannonball
            during T0 to T1 is equal to the x-component of the relative
            position of the castle with respect to the cannon.

            DT19A sky diver of mass 80.0 kg (including parachute) jumps off
            a plane and begins her descent. When the sky diver descends
            to a certain height from the ground, she deploys her
            parachute to ensure a safe landing. (Usually the parachute
            is deployed when the sky diver reaches an altitude of about
            900 m or 3000 feet.) Ignore any horizontal motion of
            the sky diver.

            For an object falling through air at a high speed v, the drag
            force acting on it due to air resistance can be expressed
            as F = K*v^2, where the coefficient K depends on the shape
            and size of the falling object and on the density of air.
            For a human body, K is roughly 0.25 kg/m. Use this value for
            K to find the magnitude of the terminal velocity of the sky
            diver before deploying the parachute.
            Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]






            When the parachute is fully open, the effective drag
            coefficient of the sky diver plus parachute increases to
            60.0 kg/m. Find the terminal speed of the sky diver after
            the parachute is opened.
            Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]

            to the coffee filter by all forces during this 1.83 s?

            POW3A47782What is the maximum constant velocity with which a
            2000 W motor could lift a 100 kg crate straight upward?

            LMOM5127757A bullet of mass 30 g and velocity 300 m/s in the x-direction

            through the pendulum bob. The pendulum bob is supported by

            in a complete vertical circle. (You may assume that
            the pendulum bob does not lose any mass.)

            to have this acceleration?

            stage.

            of the gravitational field with height.
          • Rotational Dynamics
            DR8A813.572A horizontal uniform beam of mass 12.4 kg is 2.7 m long. It is
            pivoted at a point 1.2 m from the left end. A crate hangs by a

            acting at the right hand end. What downward force must be
            applied at the left hand end in order for the beam to be in
            rotational equilibrium?
            [XXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            Note: do not neglect the weight of the beam itself which acts
            on the midpoint (cm) of the beam.

            and a mass of 0.95 kg is pivoted about one end.

            below. What initial angular velocity must the bar have
            to reach a straight up position and still have
            an angular velocity of 0.42 rad/s?
            [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            Let the initial height of the bar, measured at cm, be zero.
            EROT31366.589.5As shown in the figure below, a hoop with a 0.25 m radius
            is at the bottom of a 20 deg incline and is headed up
            the incline with an initial velocity of 4.3 m/s.
            If the hoop rolls without slipping, what distance, d,
            will the hoop roll up the incline before it momentarily
            comes to rest?
            [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            Let the initial height of the hoop, measured at cm, be zero.
            Use the center of mass (cm) to describe the translational
            motion of the hoop.
            EROT44689A tire with a radius of 0.3 m, a mass of 10 kg and a moment
            of inertia of 0.5 kg*m^2 starts from rest at the top of a
            15 deg incline that is 5.2 m long. If the tire rolls without
            slipping, what will be the magnitude of the velocity of
            the tire when it reaches the bottom of the incline?
            [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            Let the initial height of the tire, measured at cm, be zero.
            Use the center of mass (cm) to describe the translational
            motion of the tire.

            The mass density of water is 1.0e3 kg/m^3

            FLUIDS550188A water tower has a cross-section of 100 m^2, and is open at the top.
            There is a hole in the side of the tank at a position that is 10 m below
            the waterlevel in the tank at this instant. The area of the hole is 10 cm^2.
            Find the magnitude of the velocity of the water exiting the hole.

            Remember that wherever the water is open to the air, the pressure
            must be one atmosphere. The mass density of water is 1.0e3 kg/m^3.
            Take the zero-level of height to be at the surface of the water.
            Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]

            the water (which will be the speed at which the water level is descending)

            Remember that wherever the water is open to the air, the pressure must be

            Take the zero level of height to be at the level of the hole.

            FLUIDS1363785A scuba diver in full gear weighs 850 N. In order to make himself
            neutrally buoyant in fresh water he must add 8 kg of lead weights.
            The density of fresh water is 1000 kg/m^3 . Ignoring the volume
            of the lead weights, what is the average density of the scuba
            diver and his gear?
            Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            Take 'diver' to mean the diver together with his gear.
            Assume the weights rest on the diver's back.
            Hint: consider the compound body of diver and weights.
            FLUIDS14616.575A helium balloon has a volume of 1.57 m^3 when it is fully inflated.
            What is the maximum mass that can be supported by this balloon in air?
            The density of helium is 0.179 kg/m^3. The density of air is 1.29 kg/m^3.

            Take the mass of the balloon surface to be included as part of the
            supported mass, and treat the weight of the balloon itself as entirely
            due to the weight of the helium filling its volume. You may consider
            the balloon and mass as a compound body.
            Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]

              Newton's laws must be applied to individual bodies only.

              DT19A sky diver of mass 80.0 kg (including parachute) jumps off
              a plane and begins her descent. When the sky diver descends
              to a certain height from the ground, she deploys her
              parachute to ensure a safe landing. (Usually the parachute
              is deployed when the sky diver reaches an altitude of about
              900 m or 3000 feet.) Ignore any horizontal motion of
              the sky diver.

              For an object falling through air at a high speed v, the drag
              force acting on it due to air resistance can be expressed
              as F = K*v^2, where the coefficient K depends on the shape
              and size of the falling object and on the density of air.
              For a human body, K is roughly 0.25 kg/m. Use this value for
              K to find the magnitude of the terminal velocity of the sky
              diver before deploying the parachute.
              Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]






              When the parachute is fully open, the effective drag
              coefficient of the sky diver plus parachute increases to
              60.0 kg/m. Find the terminal speed of the sky diver after
              the parachute is opened.
              Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]

              FLUIDS1363785A scuba diver in full gear weighs 850 N. In order to make himself
              neutrally buoyant in fresh water he must add 8 kg of lead weights.
              The density of fresh water is 1000 kg/m^3 . Ignoring the volume
              of the lead weights, what is the average density of the scuba
              diver and his gear?
              Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
              Take 'diver' to mean the diver together with his gear.
              Assume the weights rest on the diver's back.
              Hint: consider the compound body of diver and weights.
              FLUIDS14616.575A helium balloon has a volume of 1.57 m^3 when it is fully inflated.
              What is the maximum mass that can be supported by this balloon in air?
              The density of helium is 0.179 kg/m^3. The density of air is 1.29 kg/m^3.

              Take the mass of the balloon surface to be included as part of the
              supported mass, and treat the weight of the balloon itself as entirely
              due to the weight of the helium filling its volume. You may consider
              the balloon and mass as a compound body.
              Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]

              the acceleration of block 1.
              [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
              Assume that the small pulley is frictionless.
          • F = v*abs(dmdt)  thrust force (magnitudes)
            • Linear Momentum
              ROC1277.592What is the magnitude of the thrust of a rocket
              that has an exhaust speed of 5000 m/s relative to
              the rocket and burns fuel at a rate of 18.8 kg/s?
              [XXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
              Ignore gravity.
              Assume the rocket is moving to the right.
              ROC238384Determine the exhaust speed necessary to give a 1200 kg
              rocket fired vertically from the earth an acceleration
              of 16 m/s^2 upwards if the rate of burning fuel is 60 kg/s?
              [XXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
              ROC338873Determine the exhaust speed necessary to give a 1200 kg
              rocket fired horizontally on the earth a horizontal
              acceleration of 16 m/s^2 if the rate of burning fuel
              is 60 kg/s?
              [XXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
              Assume the rocket is moving to the right.
              ROC431285A rocket mounted vertically on the earth has an acceleration
              of 0.200*g when it is initially ignited. The initial mass of
              the rocket and fuel is 1.00e5 kg and the exhaust speed of
              the combustion products is 5000 m/s relative to the rocket.
              What is the rate at which this rocket must ``burn'' its fuel
              to have this acceleration?
              [XXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
              ROC642693A rocket mounted vertically on the moon has an acceleration
              of 0.200 g when it is initially ignited. The initial mass of
              the rocket and fuel is 1.00e5 kg and the exhaust speed of
              the combustion products is 5000 m/s relative to the rocket.
              What is the rate at which this rocket must ``burn'' its fuel
              to have this acceleration?
              [XXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
              Note: the gravitational acceleration on the surface of
              the moon is 1.62 m/s^2.
          • F_x = -v_x*dmdt  thrust force (x components)
          • F_y = -v_y*dmdt  thrust force (y components)
          • F = K*v^2  drag force
            • Translational Dynamics
              DT19A sky diver of mass 80.0 kg (including parachute) jumps off
              a plane and begins her descent. When the sky diver descends
              to a certain height from the ground, she deploys her
              parachute to ensure a safe landing. (Usually the parachute
              is deployed when the sky diver reaches an altitude of about
              900 m or 3000 feet.) Ignore any horizontal motion of
              the sky diver.

              For an object falling through air at a high speed v, the drag
              force acting on it due to air resistance can be expressed
              as F = K*v^2, where the coefficient K depends on the shape
              and size of the falling object and on the density of air.
              For a human body, K is roughly 0.25 kg/m. Use this value for
              K to find the magnitude of the terminal velocity of the sky
              diver before deploying the parachute.
              Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]






              When the parachute is fully open, the effective drag
              coefficient of the sky diver plus parachute increases to
              60.0 kg/m. Find the terminal speed of the sky diver after
              the parachute is opened.
              Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
        • Compound Bodies
          • M = m1 + m2 + ...  mass of compound
            • Statics
              S2D97154A package of mass 6.00 kg rests on a table. A book of
              mass 2.00 kg rests on the package.

              What is the magnitude of the normal force exerted on the
              package by the table?
              Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            • Linear Momentum
              LMOM1A45769An 84.0 kg ice skater moving at 9.50 m/s crashes into a
              stationary skater of mass 78.0 kg. If the two skaters slide
              across the ice together, how fast are they traveling?
              Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
              Note: This problem seeks a property of a compound body.
              Use the body tool to introduce a label for the compound
              before asking for "light bulb" help.
              LMOM1B37894A 100.0 kg ice skater moving at 8.20 m/s crashes into a
              stationary skater of mass 67.0 kg. After the collision the
              two skaters slide across the ice together.
              How fast are they travelling after the collision?
              [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
              LMOM4A82886A space probe including a telescope has a combined mass of
              4000 kg, and is cruising through empty space at a speed of
              15.0 m/s. The telescope, which has a mass of 1500 kg, separates
              from the probe and travels at an angle of 20.0 deg to the
              forward direction, while the probe's path is now at 5.00 deg
              on the other side of the original trajectory.

              Find the magnitudes of the velocities of the telescope and the
              probe after they separate.
              probe: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
              telescope: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            • Fluids
              FLUIDS8907.549.5A 90 kg man standing on a 10 kg piston of radius 1.2 m is in equilibrium
              due to the pressure in the hydraulic fluid below the piston.
              What is the pressure in the fluid at the location of the piston?
              Do NOT neglect the effect of the atmospheric pressure.
              Hint: You may consider the compound body of man and piston.
              Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
              FLUIDS1363785A scuba diver in full gear weighs 850 N. In order to make himself
              neutrally buoyant in fresh water he must add 8 kg of lead weights.
              The density of fresh water is 1000 kg/m^3 . Ignoring the volume
              of the lead weights, what is the average density of the scuba
              diver and his gear?
              Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
              Take 'diver' to mean the diver together with his gear.
              Assume the weights rest on the diver's back.
              Hint: consider the compound body of diver and weights.
              FLUIDS14616.575A helium balloon has a volume of 1.57 m^3 when it is fully inflated.
              What is the maximum mass that can be supported by this balloon in air?
              The density of helium is 0.179 kg/m^3. The density of air is 1.29 kg/m^3.

              Take the mass of the balloon surface to be included as part of the
              supported mass, and treat the weight of the balloon itself as entirely
              due to the weight of the helium filling its volume. You may consider
              the balloon and mass as a compound body.
              Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
              FLUIDS1549369Ice has a density of 917 kg/m^3. The density of seawater is 1025 kg/m^3.
              To determine the percentage of the volume that is submerged whenever ice
              floats on seawater, consider a floating chunk of ice with a total volume
              of 100 m^3 and find the volume of the submerged portion of this chunk.

              Hint: Represent the chunk as a compound body composed of ice_submerged
              and ice_above_water.
              Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            • Oscillations
              OSC4669.551A weight m1 hung from a spring oscillates with a
              frequency of 1.3 Hz.
              When a second mass m2 of 1.7 kg is added to the
              bottom of the spring, the system oscillates with
              a frequency of 0.79 Hz. What is the mass of m1?
              [XXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
              Use the body tool to make a compound object from
              m1 and m2.

            DR2A66375.5A 5.00 m bar lies along the x-axis. It experiences a 7.50 N
            force straight down at its right-hand end, and a 13.2 N force
            up and to the left at 30 deg above the horizontal, at a
            point P1 located 2.00 m from its left-hand end.

            What is the z-component of the net torque on the bar
            about its left-hand end?
            Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            DR2B491.583A 4.50 m bar lies along the x-axis. It experiences a 6.25 N
            force straight up at its left-hand end, and a 40.0 N force
            up and to the left at 30 deg above the horizontal, at a
            point 1.50 m from its left-hand end.

            What is the z-component of the net torque on the bar about
            its right-hand end?

            Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            DR3A78983A 5.00 m bar at 50 deg above horizontal experiences an
            8.50 N force straight down at its right-hand end. It also
            experiences a 12.0 N force at 150 deg ccw from the
            standard x-axis, at point p1 that is 1.50 m from its left end.

            What is the z-component of the resultant torque on the bar
            about its left end?
            Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]

            and is pivoted about the z-axis through its center. Calculate
            the z-component of the net torque about this axis due to three
            forces: 16.0 N down, applied to top left corner, 24.0 N down,
            applied to the top right corner, and 18.0 N, applied at 45 deg
            to the bottom right corner.
            Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            DR5A94561A square metal plate 0.18 m on each side lies in the x-y
            plane and is pivoted about the z-axis through its center.
            The net torque on the plate is 5.88 N.m in the positive z-
            direction, and is due to three forces: a downward force of
            unknown magnitude applied to the top left corner, a force of
            24.0 N down applied to the top right corner, and a force of
            18.0 N, applied at 45 deg ccw from the standard x-axis, to
            the bottom right corner.

            What is the magnitude of the force applied to the top left
            corner?
            Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            DR6A417.581.5A flywheel has a radius of 0.450 m, and is mounted on friction-
            less bearings on a horizontal shaft through its center. A cord
            is wrapped around the rim of the wheel and a steady pull of
            45.0 N is exerted on the cord.

            If the moment of inertia of the wheel is 4.00 kg.m^2, what is
            the magnitude of the angular acceleration of the wheel?
            Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            Note: treat the force the cord exerts on the rim-pt as an
            "applied" force for the purposes of this problem.

            DR8A813.572A horizontal uniform beam of mass 12.4 kg is 2.7 m long. It is
            pivoted at a point 1.2 m from the left end. A crate hangs by a
            rope from the beam, giving rise to a tension force of 19.8 N
            acting at the right hand end. What downward force must be
            applied at the left hand end in order for the beam to be in
            rotational equilibrium?
            [XXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
            Note: do not neglect the weight of the beam itself which acts
            on the midpoint (cm) of the beam.

              EROT31366.589.5As shown in the figure below, a hoop with a 0.25 m radius
              is at the bottom of a 20 deg incline and is headed up
              the incline with an initial velocity of 4.3 m/s.
              If the hoop rolls without slipping, what distance, d,
              will the hoop roll up the incline before it momentarily
              comes to rest?
              [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
              Let the initial height of the hoop, measured at cm, be zero.
              Use the center of mass (cm) to describe the translational
              motion of the hoop.
          • I = (1/12) m*(L^2 + W^2)  rectangular plate
            • Rotational Dynamics
              DR7A1093.538A square metal plate 0.250 m on each side with mass of 7.30 kg
              lies in the x-y plane and is pivoted about the z-axis through
              its center. There are three forces: 21.0 N applied at an angle
              of 30 deg to the top left corner, 18.0 N applied at an angle
              of 100 deg to the top right corner, and 24.0 N applied upward
              to the bottom right corner.

              Calculate the z component of the angular acceleration
              about this axis.
              Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
          • I12 = I1 + I2  compound body
            • Angular Momentum
              MOMR4A551.575Two disks are mounted on low friction bearings on the same
              axle and can be brought together so that they couple and
              rotate as one unit. The first disk has a moment of inertia of
              2.81 kg*m^2 and is rotating at 8.43 rad/s counterclockwise
              about the z-axis. The second disk, with a moment of inertia
              of 7.80 kg*m^2, is spinning at 15.0 rad/s in the same direction
              as the first disk.
              If the two disks are then coupled together, what would be
              the magnitude of their angular velocity after coupling?
              Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
              Note: you should use the body tool to define a compound body
              consisting of disk1 and disk2.
    • Work and Energy
      • Wnc = Wncf1 + Wncf2 + ...  work by non-conservative
        • Work and Energy
          WEQ5Suppose a 2000 kg truck is dropped from a certain height
          above the ground, starting from rest. Find the height from
          which it is dropped if it strikes the ground at 22.35 m/s.
          Neglect air resistance. Assume that the origin is at
          the ground.
          [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
          Use energy methods to solve this problem.
          E8A828.579.5A person pulls an 18.3 kg box across a floor by pulling on a
          rope with a constant force of 50.0 N. The rope is horizontal.
          The frictional force on the box is 44.8 N. Determine the
          magnitude of the velocity of the box after it has been
          pulled 5.00 m starting from rest.

          Use work energy concepts. Solutions using other methods
          will not be recognized. You may take the floor to be the
          zero level of gravitational potential energy.
          Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
          E8B671.587A person pulls an 16.5 kg box across a floor by pulling on a
          rope with a constant force of 47.5 N. The rope is horizontal.
          The frictional force on the box is 42.0 N. Determine the
          magnitude of the velocity of the box after it has been pulled
          6.50 m starting from an initial velocity of 1.18 m/s.

          Use work energy concepts. Solutions using other methods
          will not be recognized. You may take the floor to be the
          zero level of gravitational potential energy.
          Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
          E9A636.587.5A box slides a distance of 3.48 m down a plane which makes
          a 30.0 deg angle with the horizontal. The mass of the box is
          6.21 kg. The frictional force on the box is 13.1 N. What is
          the magnitude of the box's velocity when it reaches the
          bottom of the plane if it started from rest?

          Use work energy concepts. Solutions using other methods
          will not be recognized. You may take the zero level of
          gravitational potential energy to be the bottom of the plane.
          Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
          E9B73384A box slides a distance of 4.21 m down a plane which makes
          a 30.0 deg angle with the horizontal. The mass of the box is
          5.70 kg. The frictional force on the box is 12.9 N. What is
          the magnitude of the velocity of the box when it reaches the
          bottom of the plane if it started at a velocity of 1.32 m/s?

          Use work energy concepts. Solutions using other methods
          will not be recognized. You may take the zero level of
          gravitational potential energy to be the bottom of the plane.
          Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
          E10A50789A box slides across a desk starting from a velocity of
          3.28 m/s and comes to rest in a distance of 2.63 m. If
          the box has a mass of 8.13 kg, what is the frictional force
          exerted by the desk on the box?

          Use work energy concepts. Solutions using other methods
          will not be recognized. You may take the desktop to be
          the zero level of gravitational potential energy.
          Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
          E11A51092A ship which has a constant thrust of 1.65e4 N accelerates
          from rest and reaches a velocity of 4.32 m/s in 60.0 m. The mass
          of the ship is 7.00e4 kg. What is the work done by drag?
          Use work energy concepts. Solutions using other methods
          will not be recognized.

          Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
          Note: Neglect forces in the vertical direction. Treat thrust as
          an applied force due to the engine.
          WE2A30499A 100 kg box that is initially moving at 3.0 m/s to
          the right along a frictionless horizontal surface,
          as shown below, is pushed by a horizontal force of 40 N
          for a distance of 20 m. What is the magnitude of
          the velocity of the box at the end of the 20 m push?
          [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
          WE3A38499A 55 kg box is projected up an inclined plane with
          an initial speed of 5 m/s. If the height of the plane
          is 0.5 m and the incline is frictionless, what will be
          the speed of the box when it gets to the top of the plane?
          [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
          Choose the zero of gravitational potential energy at
          the bottom of the incline.
          WE4A53183A 80 kg box, that is initially sliding with a speed of 4 m/s,
          slides 6 m along a horizontal surface before reaching the top
          of a frictionless incline. While sliding on the horizontal
          surface the box experiences a constant frictional force of
          58.2 N. What will be the speed of the box when it reaches
          the flat frictionless surface at the bottom of the incline
          which is 0.4 m high?
          [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
          Choose the zero of gravitational potential energy to
          be at the bottom of the incline.
          WE5317.577.5A 20 kg box, that is initially sliding with a speed of 6 m/s,
          slides 5 m along a horizontal surface and then up
          a frictionless incline that is 0.5 m high. If the box
          experiences a constant frictional force of 39.2 N while
          on the bottom horizontal surface, what will be its speed when
          it reaches the top of the incline?
          [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
          Choose the zero of gravitational potential energy to be
          at the bottom of the incline.
          EGRAV1A space probe orbits around the earth in a stable circular
          orbit of radius r from the earth's center.
          Find the total mechanical energy of the space probe as
          as a function of the masses and r.
          total mechanical energy: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
          Note: Because this problem does not ask for a numerical value,
          you must do any necessary algebra yourself.

          Next, find the minimum work the rocket boosters on the probe
          must do so that the probe completely escapes the earth's
          gravitational field. Express your answer in terms of
          the masses and r.
          Work: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
          Ignore any change of mass of the space probe.

          POW1B372.592What is the power required for an engine to accelerate a
          1500 kg car from rest to 30.0 m/s in 5.41 s?
          Neglect any frictional forces.
          Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
          POW2A36884A coffee filter with a mass of 2.00 g falling at terminal velocity
          falls 1.00 m in 1.83 s. What is the net average power supplied
          to the coffee filter by all forces during this 1.83 s?
          Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
          POW4A86968A mass is attached to a spring with a spring constant of 45.0 N/m
          and the mass is displaced 0.300 m from its equilibrium position.
          The mass is released from rest and passes through the
          equilibrium position in 0.280 s.

          What is the average power delivered to the mass by the spring
          during this time period? Assume friction is negligible.
          Neglect forces acting in the vertical direction.
          Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
          POW4B93073A mass is attached to a spring which has a spring constant of 50.0 N/m
          and the spring is compressed 0.450 m from its equilibrium position.
          The mass is released from rest and passes through the equilibrium
          position 0.440 s later.
          What is the average power delivered to the mass by the spring
          during this time period? Assume friction is negligible.
          Neglect forces acting in the vertical direction.
          Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
          POW5A1205.557What average power output from the car's engine is required for
          a 1200 kg car to climb a 2.00 km long 11.0 deg hill in 100 s?
          Assume the only retarding force is an air drag force with a
          magnitude of 700 N and that the speed of the car is constant.
          Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]

        • Work and Energy
          WEQ4A 0.6 kg rock in space has a velocity of magnitude 2.0 m/s
          at point A and kinetic energy of 7.50 J at point B.
          What is the net work done on the rock as it moves from A to B?

          above the ground, starting from rest. Find the height from
          which it is dropped if it strikes the ground at 22.35 m/s.
          Neglect air resistance. Assume that the origin is at
          the ground.
          [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
          Use energy methods to solve this problem.
          E4A67377A 3.00 kg block is placed against a vertical spring compressed by
          0.200 m. The spring constant is 1960 N/m. After the spring is
          released, the block flies into the air.

          How high will the block go above the uncompressed spring?
          Choose the zero of the gravitational potential energy at the top
          of the uncompressed spring.
          Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
          E4B37995A 3.00 kg block is placed against a vertical spring compressed
          by 0.200 m. The spring constant is 1960 N/m. After the spring is
          released, the block flies into the air.

          Find the velocity of the block when it is 0.750 m above the
          uncompressed spring. Choose the zero of gravitational
          potential energy to be at the top of the uncompressed spring.
          Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
          E4C263.584.5A 2.50 kg block is placed against a vertical spring compressed
          by 0.150 m. The spring constant is 2020 N/m. After the spring,
          is released, the block flies into the air.
          How high will the block go above the uncompressed spring?
          Choose the zero of the gravitational potential energy to be
          at the top of the uncompressed spring.
          Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]

          is 25.0 m above the base of the roller coaster with a speed of
          3.00 m/s.

          What is the magnitude of the car's instantaneous velocity at the
          point when it reaches the base?
          Choose the zero of gravitational potential energy at the base
          of the roller-coaster.
          Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
          E5B236100A frictionless roller-coaster car tops the first hill whose height
          is 30.0 m above the base of the roller coaster with a speed of
          3.00 m/s.

          What is the magnitude of the instantaneous velocity at the
          apex of the next hill which has a height of 10.0 m?
          Choose the zero of gravitational potential energy at the
          base of the roller-coaster.
          Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
          E6A23899A hailstone falls from a cumulonimbus cloud at a height of
          9000 m starting from rest. Using energy methods, and
          assuming that the effect of air friction can be ignored, find
          the magnitude of the instantaneous velocity of the hailstone,
          just before it hits the ground. Take the ground to be the
          zero level of gravitational potential energy.
          Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
          E7A64788A spring is fixed at the top of a frictionless plane that makes
          a 40.0 deg angle with respect to the horizontal. A 1.50 kg block
          is initially 0.600 m from the end of the uncompressed spring which
          has a spring constant of 200 N/m. The block is projected up the
          plane with an initial velocity of 4.00 m/s.

          What is the velocity of the block at the instant it has compressed
          the spring 0.200 m? Choose the zero of gravitational potential
          energy at the initial position of the block.
          Answer: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]

          plane if it is to stop momentarily when it has compressed the

          position of the block.

          passes through a pendulum bob of mass 700 g. The bullet has
          a final velocity of 150 m/s in the x-direction after passing
          through the pendulum bob. The pendulum bob is supported by
          a rigid rod that has a length l and negligible mass. What is
          the maximum value of l such that the pendulum bob will swing
          in a complete vertical circle. (You may assume that
          the pendulum bob does not lose any mass.)
          length: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
        • Rotational Dynamics
          EROT257283In the figure below, a uniform bar with a length of 1.2 m
          and a mass of 0.95 kg is pivoted about one end.
          Initially, the bar is hanging straight down, as shown
          below. What initial angular velocity must the bar have
          to reach a straight up position and still have
          an angular velocity of 0.42 rad/s?
          [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
          Let the initial height of the bar, measured at cm, be zero.
          EROT31366.589.5As shown in the figure below, a hoop with a 0.25 m radius
          is at the bottom of a 20 deg incline and is headed up
          the incline with an initial velocity of 4.3 m/s.
          If the hoop rolls without slipping, what distance, d,
          will the hoop roll up the incline before it momentarily
          comes to rest?
          [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
          Let the initial height of the hoop, measured at cm, be zero.
          Use the center of mass (cm) to describe the translational
          motion of the hoop.
          EROT44689A tire with a radius of 0.3 m, a mass of 10 kg and a moment
          of inertia of 0.5 kg*m^2 starts from rest at the top of a
          15 deg incline that is 5.2 m long. If the tire rolls without
          slipping, what will be the magnitude of the velocity of
          the tire when it reaches the bottom of the incline?
          [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
          Let the initial height of the tire, measured at cm, be zero.
          Use the center of mass (cm) to describe the translational
          motion of the tire.

          separated by 1.8 mm lies in a uniform external electric
          field of 4500 N/C in the positive x direction. How much
          work would be required to rotate this dipole from alignment
          with the external field to an angle of 43 degrees with
          respect to the field?
          work: [XXXXXXXXXXXXXXX]
          Note: Define the sought as the work done by all non-conservative
          forces.

          of 1.7 T and is in the positive Y direction
